PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the proposed Australia Card legislation on the following grounds:
1. We believe that it represents potentially undesirable interference in the lives of honest Australians and is a grave interference in the civil liberties of Australian citizens;
2. That it will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud;
3. That it will create unnecessary expansion of the bureaucracy;
and calls on the Senate to reject the legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposed introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.
(2) That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive and authoritarian, and alien to the Australian way of life.

(3) That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's resorting to such a far-reaching and expensive measure to deal with the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud. We call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and appropriate departments to tackle these issues.
Your Petitioners urge those members present to reject the Indentification Card proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed national ID Card and numbering system threatens the privacy of law-abiding Australians opening the door to computer matching of personal information, will cause inconvenience to rural people in particular, and will result in massive compliance costs for private business.

That the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee Report of 1986 showed that the Australia Card will not be effective in combating taxation and social security fraud and illegal immigration, as its cost savings are based on faulty estimates.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject the Australia Card Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an International Covenant, this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protect our Australian Heritage and Christian culture and values, both in the Education System, and through the Media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland State Elections
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Honourable members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland showeth that the electoral system in Queensland, based on a 4 zonal weighted system, is an affront to democracy. The National Party under the leadership of Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen is always returned to Government with no opportunity for the voting public to bring about a change.

Your petitioners point out that under the Queensland voting system the National Party at the State Elections on 1 November 1986 managed to achieve 55 per cent of the seats with only 39 per cent of the votes. This demonstrates that 61 per cent of Queenslanders do not want a National Party Government yet received one.

Your petitioners therefore earnestly pray that the Federal Government legislates as a matter of urgency to bring about a democratic system of voting in Queensland State elections based on the principle of one vote one value.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

We the undersigned citizens, call on the Commonwealth Government to introduce a ban on smoking on flights of 90 minutes or less. This ban should be introduced irrespective of the stand-off attitudes adopted by the airlines at present.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct 86 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct 86 to 1 Jul 87 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct 86 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.

PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the Constitution so that the Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-to care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-to prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.

PETITION.TITLE: War Criminals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
If, there is to be legal process against alleged war criminals resident in Australia, the foundations of justice should be clear and equitable.
1. Let the term, ``war crime'', be first clearly defined.
2. Let specific prosecutions be swiftly launched against those individuals alleged to have committed them, thus releasing the rest of their co-nationals from unwarranted slur and suspicion.
3. Let an Australian tribunal hear the charges. Nobody should be deported to face the ``tender mercies'' of any foreign government.
4. Let the presumption of innocence until proved guilt be clearly established.
5. Let all evidence obtained from the Soviet or any other communist government be set aside and totally disregarded.
5. Let all costs of any person charged and found not guilty be paid by the Commonwealth Government so that innocent people are not financially ruined in the course of establishing their innocence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the recent general election at which the Government was returned for a third term of office, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced a range of significant changes to the structure of the Ministry and of government departments. The Parliament will shortly consider the legislation which gives effect to or flows from aspects of these changes. For the information of the Senate I wish today to outline the overall intent of the changes and their impact, including ways they may be reflected in the operations of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Since our first election in 1983 this Government has consistently developed policies to reconstruct our economy so that it can meet the challenges of a rapidly changing world trading environment. It is not simply a task for our trade-exposed sectors such as agriculture, mining or increasingly manufacturing and tourism. It is a task for the whole economy, because all sectors can suffer if one is inefficient. In applying measures to deal with the responsible reconstruction of the economy, we are determined to apply the same rigour to the Government's own household.
Ministerial and Administrative Arrangements

Honourable senators will be aware that early in its life, this Government embarked upon a program of reform of public sector administration. In pursuing a sound administrative basis for the development of its policies, the Government has addressed fundamental issues and implemented far-reaching reform measures. The reforms were given legislative basis in the 1984 Public Service reform package, and have been augmented progressively by Budget reforms, the 1986 streamlining measures and, perhaps most importantly, the arrangements announced last July by the Prime Minister.

The Government has been concerned with two basic objectives: to enhance ministerial control over the Public Service and to give to departmental managers more responsibility for day to day management. By establishing mechanisms for greater ministerial control, we have been intent upon increasing the responsiveness of the bureaucracy to the Government's wishes and upon increasing democratic accountability, through Ministers, to Parliament and the community. The second of the objectives, greater responsibility for departmental management, has entailed the devolution of management functions from central agencies to individual departments and a new emphasis on the development of management skills in senior public servants. With greater freedom to manage, departments are in a better position to demonstrate their success in achieving the dual aims of increased efficiency and financial savings.

The Government's previous reform measures have resulted in considerable progress towards the achievement of our objectives. The revamping of Budget processes has given Ministers more direct involvement in the way resources are used within their portfolios. The introduction of program and staff budgeting has allowed the Government to tighten up resource allocation, while giving to secretaries and other departmental managers greater freedom and responsibility in applying resources to the implementation of Government policies. The major package of measures announced by the Prime Minister last year resulted in an important streamlining of personnel management practices.

With this experience behind us, the Prime Minister decided after the Government's re-election to proceed further along the path of administrative reform. The administrative arrangements approved by the Governor-General in Council on 24 July represented perhaps the most far-reaching reshaping of the Federal machinery of government and of public administration in our history. The number of departments has been reduced from 28 to 18, providing scope for savings through economies of scale and the removal of overlap and duplication across many areas of hitherto separate bureaucratic units.

To provide for enhanced ministerial control over the new range of departments, any of which are significantly enlarged, the Prime Minister decided, following receipt of an opinion from the Solicitor-General, that it was time we adopted a two-level ministerial structure and increased the number of Ministers. Under the new arrangements, the burden of administering department is shared, and portfolio Ministers are released from some detailed administrative work, enabling them to give greater attention to strategic directions of policy and priorities. All portfolios are represented in Cabinet without the need for Cabinet to be expanded to an unmanageable size. I am pleased to report that these arrangements have been in place now for seven weeks and are working well.

Portfolio Ministers are ultimately responsible for the administration of their entire portfolios and will be accountable to the Parliament for the overall operation of their portfolios. All Ministers, however, have a clear accountability within specific responsibilities allocated to them. This accountability includes responding to questions without notice in the Parliament. The Prime Minister announced the allocation of responsibilities on 11 August, but for the information of the Senate, Mr President, and as a guide to honourable senators in the direction of questions, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list showing the division of functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Within their areas of responsibility all Ministers will be available to answer questions in the Parliament, and will, of course, take an active role in the legislative process. Within the Parliament, the changes will bring a number of benefits. The combination of the additional Ministers, and of portfolio Ministers having a wider spectrum of responsibility across major sectors of government activity, means that Ministers will be placed in a better position to be responsive to the Parliament. This will apply particularly in the Senate, where The number of Senate Ministers will have been increased from six to eight, after Parliament enacts the relevant legislation, thus augmenting the capacity of the Government to respond to the concerns in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I should add that, in the meantime, pending the amendment of the Ministers of State Act to permit the appointment of 30 Ministers, there are three Parliamentary Secretaries, two of whom are in the Senate. It is intended that the people holding these positions will be sworn as Ministers as soon as possible. Until that time, as they are not Ministers, they will not answer questions without notice, carry legislation or perform chamber duty.

In allocating functions among departments we have been able to provide for improved co-ordination and broader perspectives within portfolios. We have increased our capacity for imposing functional and strategic directions on government activity in the major areas of economic reform on which Australia's response to the challenges of a highly competitive international environment depends. The new arrangements allow for greater speed and consistency in the delivery of services and advice to the public.

The abolition of the Public Service Board takes its place in this package of reforms designed to eliminate duplication of functions and as a further step in the process of increasing departmental responsibilities. All operational aspects of personnel matters are now to be devolved to departments. A new office of Public Service Commissioner will have responsibility for the policy aspects of recruitment, promotion, mobility, discipline and retirement, and for monitoring continuing progress in relation to equal employment opportunity. A part time Public Service Management Advisory Board will advise the Government on significant issues relating to the management of the Public Service. Public Service pay and conditions matters are to be transferred from the Board to the Department of Industrial Relations; and some aspects of classification issues have been transferred to the Department of Finance.

The services of Mr David Block, of which the Government has been most appreciative, will continue to be available to the Prime Minister and the Government. His unit, now called the Administrative Reform Unit, is currently overseeing the preparation of reports on matters such as the possible integration of Social Security and Commonwealth Employment Service local offices, the use of the Department of Social Security as a payment agency, a single foreign service and the future of the National Capital Development Commission.

The task the Government has set itself in this area is wide-ranging and ongoing. To ensure that it receives proper co-operation and sustained momentum a special committee of the Cabinet has been set up, under the chairmanship of Ralph Willis, specifically to address Public Service Reform.

The revised ministerial and administrative arrangements which I have summarised today are an important part of the Government's strategy of concentrating on its policy priorities while working within a streamlined structure which reflects both the need for financial restraint and the importance of responsiveness and effectiveness. I believe that the arrangements will provide a sound basis from which to undertake the tasks of meeting the present and future policy needs of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some two days before the last Federal election Mr John Ridley, the then Director of the Victorian Branch of the Liberal Party of Australia, did make some allegations referring to the electorate of Aston in which he said that one elector received an Australian Labor Party how to vote card within that person's postal ballot papers. I might say that, from my experience of elections, I have never known a campaign to go by in which some similar allegation has not come to my attention or someone else's attention. Quite simply, what normally happens is that political parties distribute how to vote cards by mail or by letter-boxing. People pick up their postal ballot papers with the rest of the material and get them mixed up in that process. Mr President, I ask you: What sort of genius would it take to put a mole in the Electoral Commission to put only one how to vote card in one set of postal ballot papers in a seat that needed 6 per cent of the vote to lose. What sort of a genius in politics would it take to work out that scheme?

ANSWER.PARA: The Electoral Commission, on the day that those allegations were made, investigated the claims. It took statements from everyone working in the Aston electoral office and it found there was absolutely no case to answer. The southern division of the Australian Federal Police also investigated that incident and also found that there was no case to answer. I might point out that in that electorate Mr Saunderson, the Labor Party candidate, posted his how to vote cards to every elector rather than letter boxing them. This allegation got a lot of publicity. The main reason it got publicity was, I think, the inexperience of certain journalists. Those of us who are heavily involved in politics know that this sort of accusation comes out at every election. Indeed, the same allegation was made just some months before in respect of the Central Highlands by-election in Victoria. That allegation was investigated by police and the same conclusion was reached as was reached in the Aston case-that is, that there was a misunderstanding by the recipient of the postal ballot papers and that there was no wrong-doing by the Electoral Commission.

I conclude on this note: I know that in the heat of campaigning people think that by throwing out some wild allegation they will get some political gain. We have all done that, but the unfortunate thing in this case is that honourable senators opposite are denigrating people who are working for the Electoral Commission and who basically cannot defend themselves. I think the Australian Electoral Commission has always had a reputation for impartiality. Having impugned it for cheap political opportunism, it is no wonder that Mr Ridley had to resign some weeks after the election.

ANSWER.PARA: The Heritage Foundation where Mr Moore worked while in the US has just published an article by him called `Kangaroo Economics'.

I do not know whether Mr Moore did work for the Heritage Foundation in the United States, but if he did he did so while he was also being paid by the Australian taxpayer. I doubt that he was formally working for the Heritage Foundation although I understand that he wrote an article called `Kangaroo Economics' which that organisation published.

Mr Moore left Australia on 27 August 1986 to begin a senior executive fellowship-that is, a training scheme financed by the taxpayers and administered at that time by the Public Service Board in which senior public servants undertake overseas visits of up to three months duration in order to pursue projects of interest to their departments and to the Public Service. Mr Moore began such a fellowship on 27 August 1986 and returned to duty in the Treasury on 5 January 1987, the day before it was reported in the Australian that he had resigned. As I said before, I think that report was not strictly correct; I think that he retired rather than resigned. If Mr Moore wants to say much more about double dipping, sponging and freeloading, I suggest that he clean up his own nest before he starts looking into somebody else's.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is there any chance of the Australian Government being able to recoup any of the $30,000 from Mr Moore, that being the cost of his visit overseas on behalf of the Australian Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I do not recall making that statement when, as Senator Lewis said, the level of the Australian dollar was US60c. If he checks his facts-and he can ask me the question again tomorrow-I think he will find I did not make that statement when the level of the dollar was about US60c.
—You asked the same question last session.
—The honourable senator is still here; I had forgotten about him. I would be very grateful to see the speech in which I referred specifically to the level of the dollar in those terms.
—You're about to get it.

—I am not about to get anything; he is about to get it. I am not like other senators who have time to read their own speeches all the time, particularly in the middle of Question Time. ANSWER.PARA: I do not in any way resile from the fact that I believe that I said on a number of occasions during last year that my anticipation was that the level of the dollar would remain for some period in the mid-sixties. According to those surveys, the anticipations are better, and I believe that throughout significant sections of the manufacturing sector the actual performance is better than the aggregate figures currently reveal.

Address by Senator the Hon. J. B. Button, Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce at the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association Canberra International Motor Inn Monday 22 September 1986.

I am very pleased to be here at your annual dinner. With the finalisation of the heavy engineering industry package in June and the recent establishment of the Heavy Engineering Board (HEB) this is a very opportune time for me to explain and emphasise the Government's preferred approach to support for the industry.
As you all are keenly aware the balance of payments deficit is placing a constraint on the growth potential of the Australian economy and on the living standards of all Australians.

The problem has its roots in our over dependence on the export of commodities-agricultural products and minerals. High inflation and low productivity growth over many years have sapped our competitiveness and resulted in the contraction of our industrial base.
The poor medium term prospects for our agricultural and mineral commodities exports means that manufacturing and services sectors must improve their performance significantly.

The depreciation of the Australian dollar to a level just above 60 cents to the US dollar has substantially restored Australia's international competitiveness and will provide major opportunities for import replacement and economic growth.

Manufacturers should be making their investment plans on the basis that the dollar will remain very close to its current levels and that the government will successfully influence the course of wage and price growth to preserve gains we have made in international competitiveness.

The heavy engineering industry is in an excellent position to benefit from the dollar depreciation because 80 per cent of components and materials inputs can be sourced domestically. I am aware that a number of heavy engineering companies have found new export markets and many more are actively searching them out.

Whether the industry's potential is fully realised is going to depend on whether it is willing to make the necessary structural adjustments and attitudinal changes. The growing willingness to tackle undesirable work practices is a good start. We also have to acknowledge and use our undoubted engineering knowledge and skills rather than believing that we always have to rely on overseas expertise. We have to obtain that recognition from the wider community.

I believe the government is establishing the right macroeconomic settings for industry. It is also attempting to get the microeconomic settings right as well and in a number of sectors including heavy engineering is taking on a role as a catalyst for and a facilitator of industry restructuring.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister is no doubt aware of the many claims that the number of days lost due to industrial unrest is excessive and out of hand. Can the Minister elaborate on the recent Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures showing that the number of working days lost in the year to May 1987 was the lowest since 1968-fewer than 200 working days lost per 1,000 employees, compared to 832 working days lost per 1,000 employees under the Howard-Fraser Government? Do not these figures indicate that the great majority of employers and employees have behaved most responsibly, in particular in contributing to employment growth of 2 per cent during the year ending May 1987?

—It greatly relieves me of my obligations as a Minister when Senator Crowley not only poses the question but gives the answer in the same breath. The figures stated in her question, if she wishes me to confirm them, are correct. They are based on the ABS figures of 4 September 1987, which show that the level of industrial disputation is at a near record low since the figures have been kept. The number of working days lost in the year to May 1987 was the lowest since 1968. There were 1.13 million working days lost due to industrial disputes during the year to May 1987, a 20 per cent drop on the number lost during the previous 12 months and a 71 per cent drop on the number of working days lost during the 12 months to May 1982, during the period of the Howard-Fraser Government.
—What about the days affected by work bans?
—How is the coal industry going-and the North West Shelf?

—It is not the responsibility of any government if somebody puts on a work ban somewhere or if there is a dispute in the coal industry. Honourable senators opposite know that. If it is a question of government responsibility, honourable senators opposite have a lot to answer for because in their last year in government, 1982, this country had the worst record of industrial disputation for years. The figures for 1987 represent a 71 per cent drop on the figures recorded under the Fraser Government. I am surprised at these silly interjections which have provoked me to draw the Senate's attention to some unpalatable facts for the Opposition. The figures demonstrate how the great majority of employers, unions and employees have recognised their special responsibilities, imposed by difficult world economic conditions. They have been able to discharge those responsibilities due to the environment created by a government which has dedicated itself to improving this situation.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and, in a sense, follows the question he has just answered, asked by Senator Crowley. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that, in terms of the reduction in the number of industrial disputes which has occurred over recent years, there was a 55 per cent reduction in 1982, a 30 per cent reduction in 1983, during part of which, of course, the Fraser Government was still in office, a 0.8 per cent reduction in 1984, a 7.6 per cent reduction in 1985 and an increase of 6.5 per cent in 1986? I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the bulk of the substantial reduction in the number of industrial disputes, of which he is so proud, occurred during the period of the Fraser Government and is a reflection of the inter- national recession which affected this country? Is it not a fact that at the moment the largest single investment project in this country, the North West Shelf, is strikebound? Is it not a fact that our first or second largest export industry, the coal industry, is also strikebound? Is the Minister saying that none of that is the responsibility of his Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know where Senator Chaney gets those questions from. Sure, there was a reduction in industrial disputes in 1982; my God, there needed to be. How did the then Government attain that reduction in industrial disputes? It was by having the greatest number of Australians out of work since the Great Depression. That is how the Liberal Party did it when in government. That is how it reduced the number of industrial disputes in 1982. The gentleman creeping forward to the table, Senator Stone, was a principal adviser of the Government of the day. He saw to it that the greatest number of Australians since the Great Depression were unemployed in 1982. That is how that figure was brought about.

ANSWER.PARA: I concede that in 1987 there are strikes in the coal industry. There are strikes on the North West Shelf. Most of those coal strikes relate to a major structural problem in the industry, as there was in the steel industry in 1982 which the Fraser Government walked away from and did nothing about. As has happened with the coal industry before, Liberal governments have walked away from these issues. This Government has not. One can go around the country from time to time and find various industrial disputes taking place. That is inevitable. It is a question of what the government of the day does about them that is important in terms of allocating responsibility as Senator Chaney seeks to do by the last part of his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take the Minister's answer to be a concession that the major drop in industrial disputes did in fact occur in 1982 and 1983 because of the substantial level of unemployment which occurred in that year. Does the Minister also concede that that substantial unemployment flowed from excessive wage rises which were extorted from the system by the trade union movement in 1981 and 1982?

—I concede that in 1982 wage levels in this country were too high given the overall economic performance of the country over a number of years. Wage levels were too high, particularly in 1982 because the Prime Minister of the day in 1981 walked away and went to a royal wedding instead of dealing with the question of wages policy which confronted this country. There was no wages policy in this country in 1981 and 1982. Senator Chaney cannot claim to have succeeded in 1981, 1982, 1983 or 1987 for that matter in attaining a substantial, significant and ongoing reduction in real wages in this country as this Government can. He cannot claim that at any period of his Liberal Government a growth in employment as this Government can in the last four years. Senator Chaney can claim none of those things. If he seeks to make comparative claims about the performance of Liberal and Labor governments on these issues, none of those things are things Senator Chaney ought to boast about and, if I might give him a word of fatherly advice, they are not even things about which he ought to lead with his chin at Question Time.

That Bill lapsed, but in October 1986 Mr J. G. Sheeron, MBE, in his presidential address, said that under the 1979 Act the industry had obtained regulations which would give the Committee the power to make determinations regarding the areas of distribution of bread manufacturers, the jurisdiction of the Committee in respect of disputes between the various sections of the bread industry and the giving of directions or advice by the Committee to the various sectors not to deliver or accept bread delivery. Finally, I ask whether he recalls hearing Senator Gietzelt, responding to Senator Vanstone's urgency motion on 13 May, say:

Does the Minister agree that Mr Morris was at all times aware of matters concerning the contract? Why has the man responsible for the Coastwatch fiasco not resigned as he obviously should do, consistent with interpretations of ministerial responsibility much narrower than those Senator Evans sought to apply to others in 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question but that the broad guidelines that the Government lays down for the conduct of tendering processes were followed in this instance and there is no question of any impropriety or lack of probity in the operation of the tendering process in this instance-certainly not on the basis of any of the material that I have seen or that has been sighted by the senior officer whom I have had reviewing this whole vexed question on my behalf in recent weeks. What has become apparent, and what I have frankly admitted in public statements on this subject in recent days, is that there were deficiencies in the detailed administration of aspects of that tendering process. There were failures to fully secure an evidentiary foundation for some rather confident conclusions about managerial and technical competence that were communicated in the tender board's report and in other minutes and other material that was communicated to the Ministers of the time. Let me make it clear that Mr Morris was the Minister at all relevant times but he had no personal involvement in terms of any--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me finish the sentence. Mr Morris had no personal involvement in the matter until after the particular contract had been signed. The material relating to the acceptance of the tender, the conduct of the Cabinet submission which sought endorsement for the necessary financial authority for the tender to proceed and the actual signing of the contract were all carried out by an Acting Minister in Mr Morris's absence overseas.
—Who was the Acting Minister?

—The Acting Minister was Mr Scholes. He acted on the basis of submissions, minutes and tender board reports, all of which I have closely reviewed. Every one of those documents addressed itself to technical and managerial questions and did so in the terms of the most robust conviction that these tests had been satisfied. Let me give the Senate one example. I will quote--
—Why was it given to Scholes?
—If the vision in pink over there, Mr President, stopped haranguing me, I would be only too pleased to communicate my perception of this state of affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me give one example of the kind of thing that was contained in the tender board's report which was on the desk of the Ministers concerned, or at least Mr Scholes, at the relevant time, before the contract was awarded. The contract was in the following terms:
Aviation have given Amann and Gosner-
that was the chief pilot in question-
a clean bill of health, both as to proposed aircraft and technical competence.

It subsequently became clear well after the contract had been awarded that the particular clean bill of health that the Department of Aviation had given was nothing of the kind, that all that the Aviation officer who had been involved in a desultory fashion in this process had addressed himself to was the question of whether there was likely to be any difficulty in Amann Aviation securing an air service licence in due course without undue delay. There was never any particular question about that. What there was a question about, which subsequently came to light, was the level of aviation expertise that was available to the tenderer which did raise very serious questions as to whether or not it would be able to perform the contract or meet the contract obligations within the time available.

There are many matters of this kind, all of which are spelt out in my Press release of a couple of days ago, and all of which will be evident in the documents that I am very happy to make available. This has been the subject already of a freedom of information application and as soon as the necessary scrutiny has been done to apply FOI guidelines relating to commercial in-confidence and so on-that material will be made available in a matter of days-it will become perfectly apparent to anyone viewing this material that what occurred is as I have described it.

There were administrative failings within the tender evaluation process which were simply not apparent and could not have been apparent to the Ministers who were handling the matter in the way that they did. When the matters did come to light about the nature of these failings and when questions did arise in Ministers' minds as to whether or not the contract could or would be able to be satisfied, the difficulty confronting the Ministers and the Government was that there was no way at that stage that the contract could have been terminated. There were no contractual deadlines earlier than 12 September and it was not at all clear right up until 12 September that the contract, despite the considerations to which I have referred, would not be able to be honoured. That was the difficulty that was confronting people such as the Minister, Mr Morris, and Senator Gietzelt, representing him in this place, as they responded to questions over that period. The key statement was that made by Mr Morris in answer to a question without notice on 7 May when he said:

The contract that has been let imposes obligations on the firm concerned. That firm has a responsibility to carry out its obligations. If that responsibility is not met, it will be dealt with at that time.

Well, the time has now come and the Government, as is now well known, has acted on the contract. There was nothing in any of the responses or any of the behaviour of any of the Ministers that were involved in this matter at any stage which is colourable in the way that the Opposition has sought to assert.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I remind the Minister again of his definition in 1982 of ministerial responsibility. I ask: Which Minister of the Hawke Labor Government was responsible for the control of this issue of the contract and the calling of tenders?

—In response to that question, the short answer is that it is the Minister for Transport or the Acting Minister for Transport, as the case may have been at the relevant time, because the Department of Transport had the managerial conduct of the tendering process and the award of the tenders. The whole question of coastal surveillance is much complicated by the fact that a number of other Ministers have an involvement in it, including the former Special Minister of State through his responsibility for the Australian Federal Police which had responsibility for the general oversight of coastal surveillance, and so on. In terms of the managerial conduct of the tendering process, that is squarely the responsibility of the Department of Transport and the Minister for Transport or the Acting Minister for Transport. There is no mystery about that.

All this sort of stuff and the effluent to say that it's dangerous and all the rest of it of salt water you ought to know that. If you don't know it, but if you knew all the facts as I'm sure you must know, . . .

While the Commonwealth acknowledges serious concerns not only about the project itself but about the Premier's knowledge of it, it has to acknowledge that it is outside the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, and while expressing concern, I am afraid that I cannot take any further action.

So I explained to him the difference between civil and common law. Mr Hazell then went on:
I believe the only one would be Hong Kong.
Mr Hazell continued:

In Europe we went to France and Belgium. Then we visited Israel, Hong Kong, the USA and Canada. Canada and the USA have very common systems but I am afraid the implication of your question is still lost on me.

This is one of the people responsible for putting together the regime to back up and enforce the Australia Card legislation. These people do not know the difference between common and civil law. They do not know the purport of having a common law system to protect our rights and liberties. Not only are they impervious to it but they do not even take it into consideration as they proceed with their plans.

In the last couple of weeks public opinion on the Australia Card has shifted dramatically. It has shifted as the opportunity has presented itself to the Australian people to get a clearer understanding of what it is that this Government has in mind: a message that has been hidden from the people both by the Government and by the dereliction of duty on the part of the Australian media to put the facts before them. We know that in June of last year 65 per cent of Australians were allegedly in favour of the introduction of the card. We know that that number has now fallen to 39 per cent. The number against the card has almost doubled from 27 per cent to 50 per cent. The editorial writers who in October and November of last year were so in favour of all these wonderful new plans are going through a change of view. An article in the Australian Financial Review of 28 August, headed `The genuine problems with the Australia Card', concludes with these words:

It is simply obscene to use revenue arguments (``we can make more money out of the Australia Card'') as support for authoritarian impositions rather than take the road of broadening national freedoms.
The Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 7 September, headed `The doubts about Australia Card', states:
It is a gold-plated answer to the Tax Office's problems. Something not quite as cost-effective but much less capable of being abused would be preferable.
The editorial in the Australian of 10 September is headed `Closer look needed at card alternatives'. The Daily Mirror of 14 August, in an article headed `Australia Card Bill flawed', states:

Senator Susan Ryan has introduced a totally new element into the Australia Card debate by talking of possible changes to the legislation and at the same time has cast grave doubts on the Government's credibility.

It is the Government's credibility and Senator Ryan's credibility which will be tested in this debate. We know that the standard reply from Senator Walsh, and those who follow his tactics in this place, is to say: `This is all the work of those who are the friends of tax cheats and the friends of people trying to rip off the system'. We shall see tonight whether he says that if there are changes to the negative gearing arrangements, which honourable senators will recall was the argument of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about that matter just two years ago. I turn to just two examples of people who have expressed their opposition to the Australia Card. I invite Senator Ryan, Senator Walsh, Senator Tate, Senator Cook, or anybody else who is going to participate, to tell us whether these people are significant friends of cheats, frauds and bludgers. I quote from the following article written by James Murray, the religious correspondent of the Australian, on 10 September:
One of the first vocal opponents of the Australia Card was the Anglican Primate of Australia, Sir John Grindrod. . .

Are we going to say that a person such as that is part of this conspiracy-the cheats, the frauds, the bludgers, the spongers and the people who want to rip off the system? On 14 September the Anglican Church Synod in Tasmania unanimously passed a resolution condemning the introduction of the Australia Card. Are these people fools, are they misled? Are they victims of the sorts of hysterical pressures that Senator Ryan wants to say are the responsibility of the Opposition for having generated them? No. They know the truth.

We know full well that the Government is conscious of the public ground swell against the Australia Card. Poor Mr Hurford, who has had his bags packed since he magnanimously gave up his spot in the Ministry in order to take up a nice diplomatic appointment overseas, has had to unpack his bags. The Government cannot afford to send him overseas or to allow him to leave the country and cause a by-election. The same thing is happening in the electorate of Robertson. Mr Cohen is anxious to get out. One thing he learnt from opera when he was Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment is that when one gets stabbed, one does not die; one sings. He is waiting for half a chance to sing, but the Government is making sure that we do not have a by-election in Robertson for the purpose of exposing what the electorate has to say about the Australia Card.

We have seen a broad-based coalition of Australian citizens who have indicated their opposition to this card. We have seen that the Australian Privacy Foundation can put together a group of people comprising Professor Wheelwright on the one hand and Professor Chipman on the other, united in their view about the Australia Card, and distinguished Australian citizens have expressed their views on the matter. Interestingly, one of the people who has expressed his view is Ben Lexcen. People will recall the Prime Minister the other day saying on the steps of Parliament House: `Who is this Ben Lexcen fellow? What is this strange coalition that he is involved in-strange bedfellows around the place?'. What did the Prime Minister have to say in his Address to the Nation on the economic situation on 11 June 1986? We know the definition of the Prime Minister. He is the guy standing next to the sporting hero whenever there are cameras around. He said:

As Australians we take enormous and obvious delight in the achievements of international excellence by our fellow countrymen and women. Just think of Robert de Castella, Joan Sutherland, Ben Lexcen and John Bertrand . . .
It requires the same elements as have brought Deek, Joan, Ben and John to the top-

to get on with the job. Where is Ben when we need to rally the nation? It requires the characteristics that Ben has; good old Ben. What did we hear within a couple of days of his statements? The Prime Minister said: `Who is this Ben Lexcen fellow? What is he all about as far as the Australia Card is concerned?'. This level of hypocrisy would be almost mind-blowing if it were not coming so regularly from the Australian Labor Party. We know the threats to personal privacy from not having an adequate system. Senator Ryan would do well to tell us what she thinks of the behaviour of the Health Insurance Commission as far as files in the McGoldrick case are concerned, and to tell us what she thinks of the Health Insurance Commission allowing the records of abortions in a medical clinic in Melbourne to be made available to the Australian Federal Police. We wait to hear what Senator Ryan has to say in defence of the Health Insurance Commission. We wait to hear what she has to say in defence of the Commission's leaking the details of doctors' incomes to the Sunday newspapers in order to blackmail them during a confrontation with a Labor government on doctors' salaries. We wait to hear what she has to say about the fact that, when a patient went to the Southport Hospital for treatment of an asthmatic condition, by using the Medicare file number the hospital authorities were able to determine that the last occasion on which that person had been treated for an asthmatic condition was when he was in gaol. We wait to hear what Senator Ryan has to say about the civil liberties of Australians under those circumstances.

When this matter was before the Senate some time ago we were concerned about overseas experience. On 25 September last year I asked Senator Grimes, as he then was, a question about Sweden. He could not give a detailed answer-a bit like Senator Gareth Evans at Question Time today. He thought that he knew something about the matter but he certainly was not going to say anything, not the least because he would have exposed the nonsense being talked about the Australia Card. However, Senator Grimes replied to me as follows in the Hansard of 7 October 1986:

Mr Freese has specifically denied that his resignation was in any way to be interpreted as a protest against or an indication of any incapacity of the Swedish Data Inspection Board to undertake its functions in respect of the protection of the privacy and civil liberties of Swedish citizens.

Today in the Sydney Morning Herald we see part of an interview from Stockholm with the same Mr Freese in which he stated that he was `prompted to quit partly as an act of protest' because he was `fed up with the increasing computerisation of Swedish society'. He offered to come to Australia and I invite the Government to pay for him to do so. After all, it brought Lars Tegnhed from the Swedish tax board to Australia to give evidence to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I now invite the Government to invite Mr Freese to come to Australia to give public testimony and evidence about his experiences as the so-called protector of civil liberties in Sweden because he warns Australia to think very carefully about the introduction of an Australia Card system. Of course, the Government does not care about these things. Of course, it does not care about privacy. Why should it? The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has defined privacy:

Let me say as a socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . we shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

This is the same Minister who, on 18 November in the other place, admitted that the system would not be able to pick up forged cards quickly. It is the same Minister whose colleague, Mr Howe, when dealing with leaks from the Department of Social Security, put out a Press release which stated, in part:
Any organisation with extensive records is vulnerable to such approaches.

Those were the approaches to leak and to misuse information held by the Government. We know that the Government admits that the legislation is defective. Dr Blewett put out a statement on 5 February this year headed `Changes to Australia Card Bill'. The Australian of 14 August had the following to say, in an article headed `ID card flawed, Ryan admits':
At this stage I think there are some minor amendments we would be happy with . . .

Senator Ryan has said in relation to privacy protection, `Don't worry about all of these things; there is adequate protection. You will not have to spend any money to go to the Ombudsman or the AAT'. On 17 August she said that it does not cost anything to go to the Ombudsman or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This is the Minister whose Government introduced a $200 charge to take appeals to the AAT and who then said, `You can go to the AAT. You do not need to put up any money because it will help you to protect your privacy'. It will cost $200 a time to protect one's privacy against the sort of system which Senator Ryan and her Government are seeking to put in place.

One almost has to feel sorry for Senator Ryan. She was included in the Cabinet not on the basis of her number of neurons but on the basis of her number of chromosomes and was given the task, like Simon of Cyrene, of carrying the cross of the ID card the last few paces to Calvary. I can tell her that she will end up nailed on it, as will the Government on behalf of which she is attempting to make out the defence that this is a system which is needed and wanted. I do not think there has ever been such a ground swell of public opinion against this card as has been manifest in the newspapers, commentaries, marches, protests, committees and representations made to members of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still would not win an election.

—Senator Cook has been thrown into this debate once again. We will have a great deal of fun exploring Senator Cook's behaviour at a later stage, because undoubtedly Senator Collins will have some comments about border hopping pirates who fiddle with other people's backyard empires. So we will come to Senator Cook and have the opportunity to deal with him in due course. He should retain his patience because we will not ignore him; we will not overlook him. In fact, we will deal with him by name rather than by number.

SPEECH.PARA: We have made it quite clear in this debate that the Opposition has consistently stood for certain principles. We have said consistently that we will co-operate in any attempt to police the taxation system properly and fairly. And no Treasurer has a better record than John Howard in introducing legislation to that effect. We will ensure that the social security system is properly policed. We will ensure that fraud does not take place and that the concerns of Costigan, the Australian Federal Police, Inspector Merv Beck, and all of those who have raised concerns about this matter, are properly addressed. We will demand that there be a full and adequate public debate and that the Government explain, if it can, the sort of system which it is intending to put upon people. We will not see our Bicentenary marred by the turning back of the clock two centuries to a system of bureaucratic control and numbered people in this country. Whatever Senator Ryan says amounts to a defence of this Government's retreat of 200 years to the sorts of civil liberties which are unacceptable and unconscionable so far as the people of Australia are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I saw that Senator Puplick was going to make his debut as a parliamentary shadow Minister in this debate, and knowing that in the past he appeared to have some genuine interest in civil liberties, I thought that we might actually get a reasonable debate, that the tone might be raised and that we might actually get some specific expression of concern about the Data Protection Agency or its mode of operation or something to which we could respond in a sensible and rational fashion. However, my hopes were disappointed. Unfortunately, all we have had is the same old thing: hysteria, emotional claptrap, personal abuse, selective quoting from newspapers, sourced and unsourced-usually unsourced-and generally the crazy idea that, somehow because we have a number, we have something that goes back to the convict days.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I address, as I guess it is my responsibility to try to address, the nonsense we have just heard from Senator Puplick, I pose to him the question which I have posed constantly to John Howard, to Senator Chaney, and to Jim Carlton, who in those days had a bit of interest in what was happening to revenues: Where was all this concern, fear, trembling, harking back 200 years and the suggestion that the convict system was about to be restored during the eight weeks of the election campaign? If Senator Puplick now finds himself outraged to the point where he can barely speak without foaming at the mouth, why was he silent on this issue during a very long election campaign in which Mr Howard daily had numerous opportunities on television, radio and at Press conferences to point to all of these horrors? Why was Senator Puplick, a senator not renowned for his silence and restraint, never to be heard raising any of these threats of a convict system, so on and so forth? All that Opposition senators say in response to this very reasonable question put by me and my colleagues is: `It was the media's fault. We are blaming the media. We were interested in the issue but the media was not'. They scapegoat the media for failing to run the campaign which they now wish, in retrospect, they had run.

John Howard admitted in a report in the Australian Financial Review shortly after the election that the reason the Opposition had not discovered all these dreadful threats, terrors and defects in the Australia Card legislation to the extent where they might squeak up about it during the election campaign was that Opposition polling had shown that 67 per cent of the Australian people were in favour of the Australia Card.

What happened after that? There was blithering and blaming of the media. A few high profile individuals have decided that this is the best way they have ever found of getting their faces on television and have leapt into the debate, creating confusion and concern. Now the Liberals, the Johnny-come-latelys, have leapt on to the bandwagon and said, `Me, too. Me, too. We really think the Australia Card is dreadful. We forgot that it was dreadful during the election campaign, but we have discovered that it is dreadful again and we do not want the likes of Peter Garrett getting all the publicity. We want a bit of publicity, too'. So we hear the sort of thing we have heard from Senator Puplick.

Let me address some of these issues. Senator Puplick said that the worst thing about the Australia Card, a system of identification which will protect the taxpayers' revenue, stop social security fraud and reintroduce public decency and morality into the system-all of the things that the Australian people want; a simple, streamlined, straightforward identification system-is that it will have numbers, and numbers are what convicts had. With an incredible leap of illogic Senator Puplick says that because the Australia Card will have numbers and because convicts had numbers ergo the two are the same. Terrific! Senator Puplick should go back to school.

Senator Haines, who is to join the debate, is a great advocate of the tax number system. Frank Costigan, who does not like the photograph on the Australia Card, is also a great advocate of a tax number system. In fact, all members of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card argued in favour of a unique numbering system. Where they fell apart and made different reports was in respect of whether it should be a tax numbering system or an Australia Card system. On the one hand we have the likes of Senator Puplick saying, `We cannot have this system because it involves numbering' and on the other hand honourable senators opposite, such as Senator Haines, saying that they want a number system, but not the system the Government has put up.

Before we all shrivel up and die at the thought of having a number associated with us, let us remember that every Australian already has a Medicare number. That was introduced some years ago. If the mere fact of having a number attached to one's name somewhere in the system is going to bring down democratic civilisation as we know it, where was Senator Puplick, the great civil libertarian, when Medicare numbers were introduced? To follow the logic of what Senator Puplick is saying, why should we have a passport number? Why should we not be free to come and go? Why should we not let anyone come into the country? Why should we insist on a number on a passport? Is this not an invasion of our civil liberties? Driving licences will have to be abolished if Senator Puplick's stance is to have any logic, particularly those licences in States such as Queensland, which carry a photograph.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Territory.
—And the Northern Territory.
—Are they compulsory?

—If one wants to drive, of course a drivers licence is compulsory. Now Senator Puplick wants people driving on the roads without driving licences. Now he does not want driving licences to be compulsory. The irresponsibility of the kind of debate our opponents are putting up astounds even me, and I have had to put up with this sort of thing from the Opposition for 12 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick also makes a number of spurious claims about the timetable and leaked documents. He quoted in a highly selective and dishonest way from the Hansard record of the Select Committee's hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I do not mind being called disorderly but the term `dishonest' is unparliamentary, Mr Deputy President.
—To say that Senator Puplick is dishonest is unparliamentary. It should be withdrawn.

—I withdraw the term `dishonest'. Senator Puplick quoted part of an exchange between himself and an officer from the Health Insurance Commission concerning the investigation of overseas systems. He did not go on to quote the very adequate explanation given by Mr Michael Clarke, who is the officer in charge of the Australia Card Secretariat. Similarly, Senator Puplick rushes to the newspapers, finds the odd editorial that might have expressed some misgivings and quotes it. He does not bring into the Senate the dozens and dozens of positive editorials there have been in a whole range of newspapers. For those who had the misfortune of having to listen to Senator Puplick and had hoped that he might shed some light on what has become an issue of concern to the community, I am just setting out that he has, in the most gross fashion, used sources where they suited him and ignored the weight of evidence there is that the Australia Card is a system which many people judge to be in the interests of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: The wording of the urgency motion the Opposition has brought to us today refers to the need for adequate public debate. Even the most avid opponent of the Australia Card could hardly say that there has not been public debate. There has been over 40 hours debate in the Parliament, we are to have another full scale debate in the Senate and we will have further debate on the issue at the joint sitting. As well as that, speaking as someone who has been in the Australian Senate for 12 years, I have never been involved in so much concentrated media debate, which is very public as we know, on a particular issue as I have been on this issue. I am sure that other people can say the same. To suggest that somehow there has been a paucity of debate on this issue is as illogical and silly as all the other things the Opposition has to resort to in an effort to continue to blow the bushfire until it goes out.

Certain matters have been raised and, even if Senator Puplick does not want to get down to facts and real information and an accurate description of the legislation, I am prepared to do so. I want to say a few things about the civil liberties protections during the debate. My colleagues Senator Michael Tate and Senator Peter Cook will address the other matters, such as the alleged cost to business and the costing, which is very important. The Government would not be proceeding with this legislation unless we were confident that there were billions of dollars to be saved for honest taxpayers and genuine social welfare recipients.

I want to say a few things in regard to civil liberties. I want to say on the record that I recognise and acknowledge that by now, since there has been so much fear mongering and so many false things said about the legislation, there are people in the community who are genuinely concerned that there may be some impairment of civil liberties. I want to address my remarks to them because I realise that it is pointless to address my remarks to the likes of Senator Puplick. I want to go very quickly through the ways in which civil liberties will be protected and, as a preamble, say that there has never been such a wide-ranging package of civil liberties protections for the individual in relation to data kept about him or her in government and in private sources as we have here.

Another question I would like to put to Opposition senators, formally and informally, is why, if they are apparently so concerned now about the misuse of simple identity data, which is all the Australia Card database will have, have they not in the past expressed a similar or even greater concern about the enormous amount of data that is held about individuals in the private sector, with no protections, no scrutiny, no Data Protection Agency and no rights of appeal-nothing? Apparently it is all right if all the credit agencies, private finance companies and the rest of the private sector find out what they like about us and use it in whatever way they want to. In the private sector that is okay and one will never hear anything from Senator Puplick, Senator Reid or anyone else about it. But as soon as the Government wants to improve, correct, streamline and protect basic identity information it is the end of civilisation as we know it.

There are many questions to be asked but they are mainly to be asked by these newfound, born again opponents of the Australia Card, rather than the Government. However, we stand ready to answer any genuine queries that are raised with us. In relation to civil liberties I simply point out a number of things that have been raised by our opponents and make the appropriate reference to the clauses in the legislation. It might be of interest to those who are genuinely concerned with what is in the Australia Card legislation. People are under no obligation to carry the card at all times-clause 8. Card applicants have the right to object to the requirement for a photograph and specimen signature-clause 12. Card applicants have the right to object to the Authority's request for further documentation-clause 13. The Authority is restricted to obtaining information from a limited number of data banks-clause 14. Person will be given a statement of reasons if they are refused the issue of a card-clause 16, and notice if their card is cancelled-clause 19. Information shown on the card will be strictly limited-clause 17. As I pointed out, it is less information than any driver's license contains. The Authority is to maintain the Register in compliance with directions issued by the Agency, preventing unauthorised access to or disclosure of information contained in the Register-clause 24. Information to be held on the Register is clearly defined-schedule 1, and so forth. I ask for the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the list of protections and their appropriate clause number as I fear that time will not allow me to go through them all.
