TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the major questions which have been raised. The first is that as a result of this legislation the Government will collect a whole lot of new data that it does not currently have about individuals and that that will be a risk. That is wrong. As a result of the legislation the Government will authenticate identity data only-that is, seek information or use information that it currently has to establish that one is the person one claims to be. That identity data will be the only data kept in the Australia Card databank.
—Why should we have to prove that to you?

—The answer, I think, was implied in one of the questions asked in Question Time today. There are an enormous number of people, as Senator Puplick knows, who are running around this community operating under false names-operating bank accounts under false names, taking social security payments that they have no entitlement to.
—How many? Put a figure on these enormous numbers. You have the police Minister here. Tell us how many?
—Senator Puplick wants to know how many. Is he suggesting that this is not a problem?
—You are saying there are enormous numbers. We have the police Minister here. Tell us how many.

—Senator Puplick is trying to distract the debate from the fact that everybody in this chamber knows, and everybody listening to this debate knows, that there are crooks and frauds running around the community with false identities, using--
—Do you know any?

—There are thousands. If Senator Vanstone is not prepared to admit that there is a massive problem of fraud in this community, she should go back to the drawing board and read the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and other reports, that have established--
—Why is the Department of Social Security opposed to the card?

—The Department of Social Security is not opposed to the card. Honourable senators on the other side of the Senate always seem to think in terms of rich people-that is, that if a rich person says something it must be true, that we must not question what is said and that we must immediately withdraw the legislation because a rich person has said that it might inconvenience him. I wish these honourable senators would give a little thought-a very rare thing for them-to the poor people in this community. The poor people in this community do not run around with wallets containing American Express cards, Bankcards and other credit cards. The poor people cannot operate on plastic credit. They cannot go into a store and spend thousands of dollars because they happen to have a credit card which entitles them to do so. The poor people in this community deserve a better deal than they are able to get while we have this extent of fraud in the social security and taxation areas. A woman who has been deserted by her husband and needs to get a social security benefit cannot just go and get it without identification, as a rich man cannot open a bank account without some identification. Senator Puplick seems to suggest that requiring identification is a new thing that has never happened in Australia. We all know how absurd that is. A poor woman cannot go into the Department of Social Security and say that the kids are starving and that she needs money straight away. She has to establish her identity and her entitlement to that benefit.
—Why should she need an ID card?

—Senator Haines is a person who has shown some interest in poor people. The poor woman I am talking about needs an efficient, protected system which will establish immediately that she is who she is, that can be immediately used to check that she is not in employment, that she is not a fraud and that she is able to get that benefit straight away.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment-and Senator Haines might know about this because she does seem to take a bit of interest in the poor-people in that circumstance have a great deal of difficulty establishing their entitlement. The Australia Card will make it efficient, quick and honourable for that woman to get her benefit straight away. It will also mean that when all the frauds who are moonlighting and running around getting payments they are not entitled to have been weeded from the system, honest, decent social security recipients will be able to regain a reputation in our community. As it is, they are often dragged down by the cheats and frauds, and there is a backlash against them.

As we know, single mothers suffer terrible prejudice in the community, not because the community is not sympathetic with the genuine women in that circumstance, but because the community is sick and tired of frauds who give the whole thing a bad name. I ask members of the Opposition to stop and think about the advantages to poor people of having an identity system which has integrity, which is fraud proof and which provides speedy entitlements to people who have a need.

Senator Puplick raised the question of the Health Insurance Commission. Much has been made in the media lately of alleged leaks. I want to say a number of things about the Health Insurance Commission. First, in relation to the documents that are in circulation, it appears that they have come from the Commission. Let me draw the Senate's attention to a few things about them. They are not relevant to the current stage of preparation for the system. They were early working drafts of proposals and discussions. There will be no assistance from such documents to those who are interested in how the system will actually operate. Second, they have nothing to do with personal information. They are flow charts and discussions about how processes can be managed and things of that kind. They have nothing to do with individuals. They are not in any sense a violation. There will be an investigation of the Australian Federal Police into that matter and there will be an upgrading of security. My colleagues Senator Tate and Senator Cook will speak further on this.

In conclusion, I have never heard so much illogical, hysterical and abusive content as I have had to put up with in the Australia Card debate. It is simply because the people opposite never were able to produce a substantial argument against it when it counted during the election campaign. The Opposition lost the election and it is trying to have a second bite of the cherry. It will lose that too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of urgency moved by the Liberal Opposition states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for further consideration and adequate public discussion of the Australia Card in view of increasing concern about the threat it poses to individual privacy and civil liberties, the burden it places on business and industry and the failure of the Government to prove the Card will be cost-effective.

What needs to be said first and foremost is that there is no one in this chamber, I would imagine, who in any way supports tax or social security fraud. To have that allegation flung at opponents of the ID card is a childish way of attempting to rebut some fairly solid arguments. I am not going to suggest that everybody who is arguing against the card has always been putting forward logical arguments. But in the main they have been logical. The cheap shot that the only people who are opposed to it are people who have something to hide and therefore something to fear is a nonsense. It does not do any credit at all to the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) who currently has charge of the legislation. What we in this place and those in the community want in effect is a system that will work to cut back as much as possible the tax and social security fraud that we all acknowledge has got away from governments, past and present.

I agree, too with Senator Ryan that the Opposition's motion could well have included a reference to disadvantaged people as well as to the well off people who are mentioned in it. For example, it could have included some reference to those supporting parents that Senator Ryan mentioned, in particular those women who are currently escaping a violent marital relationship, and in order to do so successfully move themselves and their children to another city or to another town-maybe to the country somewhere-and without any attempt to defraud anybody at all, assume another name. But how will they be able to do that successfully when the Government introduces this sort of system?

The motion should also have included the fact that the Card will not be effective in any significant way at all in doing what the Government argues it will do; that is, eliminate or cut out tax or social security fraud. How can it? No country which currently has a system even remotely similar to this one has managed to eliminate the cash economy or get rid of the criminal element. That is as true of the psuedo-ID card system that America has as it is of the ID card systems that apply in Europe. There is no way that the cash economy or the criminal element will be affected by the national identification system that this Government is planning to use. On the contrary, the criminal element especially could well be aided by it through the system's validation of a very invalidly assumed identity. So of course we need what the urgency motion says we need: we need much more consideration of this legislation and we need adequate public discussion.

I suspect that one of the reasons why there was not an outcry from the public over this legislation during the election campaign or before it was simply that the public assumed that it did not matter if Labor got back into government as long as the Senate was not in the hands of the Government, because in the majority of cases members of the public were simply not aware of the constitutional device of having a joint sitting. They were certainly not aware that the Government was going to get the increased majority that it did. For the Government to argue that the election result provides some kind of magical mandate is an absolute nonsense. The Senate was deliberately kept out of the hands of the Government by the voters and the Government itself should pay heed to that fact. The Government needs to make a much greater effort to educate the public about the inadequacies of this legislation and to explain why it is trying to do what it is trying to do when there are so many alternatives available to it that would not be as costly, both in monetary terms and in terms of invasion of privacy, but which it does not seem to see fit to introduce.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the alternatives?

—I will come to them in a moment. To begin with the Government needs to answer the challenge from the Law Council of Australia, a not insignificant body of people, that the Government's attitude-that is, its attitude to the safeguards allegedly provided in the legislation-seems somewhat contradictory. The Law Council of Australia says:

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand it-
that is, the Government-

argues that the information contained on the Australia Card and in the central data base will be limited and of such a character that there need be no concern about its being vulnerable to unauthorised access. On the other hand, the Government sees the need to establish a complex and costly system to protect that information-a system said to be the most secure available. It might be asked why such tight security is needed if the information held is as insignificant as the Government asserts.

The Law Council goes on to point out that, of course, `the DPA will have no weapon to ensure protection of privacy', because it can only act after the event-and anybody who has read the legislation will have become aware of the fact that the penalties applying to somebody who does leak information are quite inadequate and significantly lower than those applying to ordinary individuals in the community who do not in some way comply with the requirements of this legislation.
The Government also needs to explain why it is trying to implement a supposedly high integrity system by basing it on low integrity documents. Clause 13 (1) makes the following point:

Where an application has been made for the issue of a Card, the Authority may, by notice in writing given to the applicant, require the applicant to give to the Authority, within the period specified in the notice, such information or documents as are required in the notice, being information or documents reasonably required to enable-
(a) the identity of the person in respect of whom the application is made to be verified.

Presumably that means documentation such as a birth certificate or a passport-documents which we all know are quite readily falsely acquired. Why this Government is arguing that it can produce a high integrity system based on low integrity documents and verifying data is beyond the comprehension of most people in this chamber. That point was made very strongly in the majority report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, which recommended the use of the tax file number and underlined the fact that that tax file number had to be made of very high integrity indeed for it or any other system to be workable. Indeed, the Australian Taxation Office acknowledged that at the moment the tax file number system is of appallingly low integrity. So for this Government to provide, as it has in the Cash Transactions Bill, for having verifying documentation produced to banks before bank accounts and so on can be opened and citing, in order of preference, tax file numbers, passports, and birth certificates, is to ignore the fact that this documentation is worse than useless because it can only be used to give an improper validity to something which should have no validity at all.

The Government needs to explain to the Australian public why it is putting the cart before the horse in this way and not setting about getting a better integrity for the documents that we all use from time to time to verify that we are who we say we are; why it is not getting the births, deaths and marriages registry nationalised and computerised first; why it is not ensuring that passports can no longer be got on false birth certificates; and why it is not ensuring that those birth certificates cannot be fraudulently obtained in the first place. It needs to explain why it is not using alternative methods-things like a high integrity tax file number-to crack down on the tax and social security fraud that, as I said before, we all deplore. The Government should make that system one of improved integrity. We do not need to come up with a piece of legislation that is 130 pages long, has 189 clauses in it and a schedule that contains statements such as the statement that the Government will digitise the image of the cardholder. For what purpose, one wonders. I suggest that if this legislation is enacted-if it is forced through a joint sitting-there would not be a student in the country who would be prepared to go out and protest against increased tertiary fees or a peace activist who would be game to rally at Pine Gap, without being afraid that he or she will be identified from videos of those rallies matched against the identifying data that is contained in the computer, that is, the digitised image or photograph.

Why is the Government on the one hand crowing about the effectiveness of its crack down on social security fraud, implemented a few months ago, while on the other claiming that welfare cheating is still going on significantly and can be cut back only by the introduction of an ID card of the sort that is provided for in this legislation? Why is the Government on the one hand encouraging, as it should, the Commissioner of Taxation to carry out audits on high profit making companies, raising, according to Mr Boucher recently, something like $2.5m on average from the companies so audited-indeed, he is also suggesting putting auditors permanently on the premises of some of the major companies--

TALK.START.PARA: —Excellent idea.

—I do not agree with Senator Schacht on much and I will probably agree with him on less as time goes on, but I certainly agree with him on that. Why, then, is the Government on the one hand arguing how effective these measures are in eliminating tax avoidance, evasion and fraud while on the other hand arguing that that same tax fraud can be stopped only by a national intrusive identification system? Can the Government explain, too-to me, to others on this side of the chamber and to the Australian public-why privacy legislation is to be introduced only if the ID card legislation goes through, legislation which will not in fact impinge in any way at all on the private sector, despite Senator Ryan's comments rather acidly directed at this side of the chamber earlier on?

SPEECH.PARA: We have certainly made a point, through my colleague Senator Michael Macklin, of the need for adequate privacy legislation that affects the private sector as much as it does the public sector. Can the Government explain the so-called voluntary nature of a card which has to be held by every individual who wants a rebate on medical expenses or wants to sell a home, hold down a job, collect family allowances, sell goods or undertake any of the other numerous activities that we in this country have been used to doing without being fettered in any way at all-activities that are part and parcel of a democratic country.

More importantly, can the Government explain why it has failed so dismally to inform the people of Australia that all of this is the case-that there are these problems, there are these loopholes and there are these likely infringements-that this card is in fact not like a driver's licence which, despite Senator Ryan's odd comments, is in fact an item which we hold voluntarily, which we choose to hold if we want to drive and for no other reason. The ID card is not like a bankcard with our photograph on it. It is not like the sort of ID card that some people need to carry to have access to a high security building. It is not like any of those cards and licences, because they provide access to information pertinent only to the department that is issuing them, not a sort of catch-all department administered by the Health Insurance Commission which, as Senator Puplick has already indicated, has one of the most appalling records for preserving confidentiality of any department that this Government administers.

Finally, can the Minister and the Government deny absolutely the argument put by the Society of Labor Lawyers in Victoria-which, by the way, her colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table, helped set up and was the inaugural president of-that the ID card has the potential to become an internal passport and that the data bases established by the card may in the future be used for surveillance of the entire population? Of course they cannot explain any of those things. But the public needs to be made aware of the problems and to be made aware of the deficiencies in the legislation that this Government is so proudly claiming is going to end all the rorts, welfare and tax, in the Western world as we know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Number 59687364 rises today to speak on the urgency motion before the Senate chamber. I have no doubt that if the Australia Card Bill goes through this is what will happen to every senator in this place. I do not desire a number like that to be Australia's bicentennial gift to me. This point was put so very well by Senator Puplick when he led for the Opposition in the debate this afternoon. Most certainly, I do not want to protect tax cheats or social security frauds. I would not say that anyone on this side of the chamber wished to do that. As the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) said of many of us, I hold a bankcard number. I hold a tax file number, as everybody does. I have a driver's licence with my photograph on it, because I like to drive a motor car whenever I get home and have the chance to do so. Those who receive social security benefits, I have no doubt, also have a number. What I object to, and what the Opposition parties object to, is the fact that the Government, with this legislation, wants to put all of this information together in a data protection agency. This, of course, is what we are all so very concerned about-invasion of privacy. I say first of all that I do not believe that this Labor Government has any mandate to inflict on our country this most un-Australian piece of legislation. Statistics have a way of being used and abused for the sake of an argument. However, one set of statistics clearly shows that the Hawke Labor Government does not have a mandate to implement this most dangerous threat to privacy ever to be seen in this freedom loving country. I point out that 768,527 more Australians voted for the anti-ID card parties than voted for the Australian Labor Party at the last election. The anti-ID card parties won more votes than the ALP in every State and Territory with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory. So for the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to suggest that the return of his Government is proof positive that Australians want the ID card is to prove that he has completely lost touch with Mr or Mrs Average Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that most honourable senators in this chamber have been bombarded with letters and petitions from ordinary people who are very concerned about this ID card proposal. They are concerned about what it is to be used for, who will have access to it, and that they will not be able to manage without it. Of course, they have real concerns about the ability of hackers to infiltrate the system quite easily. I was very interested to see in the Australian newspaper this morning two pages of letters to the editor from people who are very concerned about this matter. These are letters from ordinary people-not cheats and frauds, but people are concerned about this matter. The newspaper received so many letters that it felt it had to devote two pages to them. It said that of the 526 letters that were written in respect of the ID card, an overwhelming 475 were against the proposal, 25 were for and 26 were from people who did not make their ideas quite clear.

I believe that there is an increasing concern about the Australia Card and why the Government is bringing it in. The people who wrote those letters have not been organised by slick lobby groups. They are ordinary men and women who are concerned. Perhaps `concern' is too gentle a word. These people are scared stiff about which direction the socialist government that we have in power is taking them. The Government has failed convincingly to demonstrate that the ID card will achieve its stated aims. I want to put some of the facts about this ID card on record. The ID card will not stop tax fraud or evasion. The Australian Taxation Office is on record as saying so. The ID card will not catch the welfare cheats because the Department of Social Security has said so. The ID card will not catch illegal immigrants. Who said that? The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs said that, and it ought to know. Organised crime will benefit from the introduction of ID cards because it will be able to forge and use them. I believe that civil liberties and privacy are threatened by the ID card. The cost to all taxpayers will be excessive. With the introduction of this ID card, more public servants will be needed to control it. Goodness gracious me, the Government, with its deficit at the present time, ought to be thinking of ways and means of having fewer public servants rather than more. Private sector costs will also be increased by this ID card.

New personal penalties and fines will be introduced to try to ensure the ID card's complete acceptance. Actually, the Prime Minister said recently on the media that it would not be compulsory to have an ID card. That is all very well, but how is one going to get on without it if the information that we have received is correct? The Government says if one does not produce an ID card one will not be able to deposit or withdraw money from a bank, one will not be able to claim Medicare benefits, one will not be able to get a job and one will not be able to buy or sell property. So the list goes on. I inform Senator Robert Ray that that is stated in division 2 of part IV of the Australia Card Bill 1986, which deals with when the card has to be produced. Senator Tate, the then Special Minister of State, spelt it out in his second reading speech that the card would have to be produced for deposits and accounts with financial institutions, investments, income from certain trusts, primary production income, rental income and foreign remittances. Goodness gracious me, the list is as long as my arm, and my arm is fairly long. One can see that it will be necessary for people to carry and produce their ID card almost on a daily basis. These are some of the reasons why we are all very concerned about it. Democracies closest to our own such as Britain, the United States of America and Canada have all rejected national ID card proposals. Senator Puplick told us earlier about the Director-General of the Swedish Data Protection Board who resigned in protest, after 12 years in the job, because of the failure of the Data Inspection Board and the data Act to stop `our shrinking privacy and the extremely new vulnerability of the computerised society'. There I am speaking about a country which has an ID card.

Turning to the United States of America, a United States congressional report released in June this year states that the United States privacy Act is failing to give privacy protection to United States Government records. This is really what we are concerned about in this debate-the privacy aspect. When the Australia Card was first debated, 17 government agencies lobbied for access to the central identity register. The decision by the Government to allow three departments access to it has not fooled anybody. Once the card is introduced, no doubt other departments will subsequently be allowed access to the register as people start to worry less about it. Certainly, at present, everybody is very concerned. Very many eminent persons have expressed reservations about the ID card. Frank Costigan has told us in no uncertain terms what he thinks of the ID card, as have Justice Michael Kirby, Dr Ian Spry, QC, Editor of the Australian Tax Review, and the Right Reverend Michael Challen, the Anglican Bishop of Perth, who said:

No family, no community and no nation can really work very happily except on the basis of trust . . . We believe that people will require the card to be produced as a normal practice and therefore people will not be trusting one another . . . What is abnormal at the moment, we suspect, would become normal.

I do not believe, as Senator Ryan has suggested, that people such as those are tax cheats and frauds just because they are against the Australia Card. There are certainly very many people who feel very strongly about it. In fact I suggest to Government senators opposite that many people in their Party are against the introduction of the ID card. The Victorian branch of the ALP rejected the proposal for a national identity card at a State conference as far back as October 1985. The South Australian branch of the ALP has opposed a national identity card. The ALP National Conference held in Hobart in July 1986 considered, but ultimately defeated, a motion calling on the Party to reject totally any form of universal national identification card or system.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, they agreed.

—Yes, they did, but that showed to me that they did not have too many brains. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Unsworth, has warned the Federal Government that it should drop plans for the Australia Card because of the widespread and growing opposition to it. Unfortunately, at this point in time the Prime Minister has not taken any notice of him. Mr Unsworth told Mr Hawke that he should re-evaluate the proposal and take it back to the drawing board. I believe that it should not go back to the drawing board but should be thrown out completely, or at least a referendum should be held to see whether Australians want an identity system introduced. If the opinion polls conducted by the media organisations are anything to go by, I am sure that the people of Australia as a whole will say no. That is what we want. We certainly want to make sure that all Australians have a chance to say whether they really want this card or not. I am sure that an overwhelming number of Australians will say that they do not want it. The other day in Brisbane there was a march and a rally against the identity card. People such as Mr Jones and Senator Stone marched and spoke out against the ID card. Ordinary people everywhere are very concerned about the fact that the Government wants to bring in a card.
—Do you agree with marching in Queensland?

—One is allowed to march in Queensland if it is about something sensible like this. We realise that it is a very important matter. Everybody realises it, except people who strongly support and belong to the Labor Party. However, there are even members of the Labor Party who are willing to march and be counted on a subject like this. The author Mr Morris West is one of the latest opponents of the proposed Australia Card, but time will not permit me to go through all the reasons why, he says, Australia does not need a card like that. The Prime Minister and the Government have said that one of the main purposes of the card supposedly is to crack down on welfare cheats. But on the Ray Martin show the other day the Minister, Senator Ryan, admitted that an ID card would not prohibit people from obtaining employment. A person who is on the dole and who wants to go off it and do some seasonal work, bearing in mind that he will not have to produce an ID card, will still be able to work under a false name. So I really do not see that the Government is achieving anything by having this card, especially when one considers that it will cost about $2 billion to change the private sector's system and that it will cost taxpayers about $1 billion-that is a lot of money for a government that is really working hard to reduce a tremendous deficit-and when one realises that it will require 2,000 public servants to administer it.

SPEECH.PARA: These are some of the reasons why I am very pleased to support Senator Puplick's urgency motion today. I believe that Australians as a whole will give their wholehearted support to our urgency motion because they certainly re- alise that we do not need an Australia Card. The key factor of the whole debate centres around freedom and the gradual erosion of freedoms that we have enjoyed in this country. I hope that the Government will decide not to proceed with this proposal. We certainly would like to make sure that the scheme does not go forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, it ill becomes a senator who has just said that people will be given permission to march if the issue on which they march is a sensible one to talk about freedoms in this country when that is her attitude-may I say, a totalitarian attitude-to the rights of citizens in this nation to express themselves by way of peaceful demonstration and political dissent.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I have to deal with the debate as it has been brought into the chamber. It is perhaps time that we came back to the actual terms of the urgency motion before the Senate. There is a claim in the early wording of the urgency motion that there is a need for further consideration and adequate public discussion of the Australia Card in view of certain matters. As far as I am aware, there has never been any suggestion that other than very adequate time has been given for the community and indeed this Parliament to come to grips with this particular notion. It was raised as long ago as June 1985 by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the Tax Summit and has been the subject of continuous public discussion therefore for well over two years. Of course, it has been the subject, I believe, of something like 30 hours of debate in this chamber alone, let alone that which has occurred in the community at numerous rallies and meetings that have been called to discuss it.

What is really at stake in this urgency motion, though it has not been much adverted to, is that this is part of the softening-up process. What Senator Puplick is trying to get the Senate to do and to become accustomed to is the notion that we need more time. This is really part of the softening-up process to precede the filibuster that will carry through no doubt well into the autumn session next year. That is the object of this particular urgency motion-to begin that process of frustration of what is a constitutional process undertaken on 12 June when the Prime Minister visited the Governor-General. It is all very well to talk about referendums. If we are talking about the Australian Constitution, the fact is that we had arrived at a time when the impasse between the two chambers of this Parliament needed to be resolved. The Governor-General accepted and concurred in that advice from the Prime Minister and therefore gave a double dissolution. This has led to the situation where we will have a joint sitting so that the elected representatives of the people, meeting in a different structure from when they meet separately in their two Houses, can come together to vote on this matter, which was the cause for the Prime Minister successfully obtaining the concurrence of the Governor-General in the granting of a double dissolution. That is the constitutional process on which we are embarked and which needs to be resolved in a reasonably speedy time-not in a time that does not allow for adequate deliberation and debate in this chamber. We do not give up our rights to engage in those processes which are proper to us as elected representatives and parliamentarians, but the time will come, as is constitutionally provided for, when the process of joint sitting has to be undertaken. This urgency motion begins the softening up process by suggesting that there has not been enough time for discussion in the community, when this matter was introduced into public debate at the tax summit in June 1985. This is something on which we should be watchful.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen also spoke of her long arm. I was waiting for her nose to grow a little too, because some occasional little fibs were creeping in. Her assertion that the Australia Card will become something of a daily necessity is quite ludicrous. The scaremongering that has gone on among very ordinary, decent people in the community to get them into a state of almost hysteria, where they think they will have to produce this card on demand, is woeful. When I look back over the last year or perhaps two years as to the number of occasions on which I would have to produce the Australia Card under this legislation, I can think of three or four instances where I have had to obtain a Medicare benefit. I have not changed my employment-although no doubt many Opposition senators wish that I had been put in that position very recently-nor have I had to purchase a new home, nor have I had to open a new bank account. In fact, most Australians will have to produce this card, apart from the normal Medicare arrangements, perhaps only twice a year, three times in two years. The claims and the scaremongering that somehow we are introducing an internal passport, some sort of system which will require production on demand, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, on a daily basis, are so far removed from reality as to lead to the conclusion that there is a deliberate attempt to arouse hysteria and emotions among people who, when they come down to it, can see the good sense of this proposal.

After all, what is the card about? I am not saying that Opposition senators are friends of tax cheats and of those who would defraud the social security system. It is a question of a simple photographic card which has to be produced on those occasions when by manipulating one's claim to an identity, one can avoid making a proper contribution to the revenue by way of taxation, or obtain a benefit from the social security system or under Medicare. Senator Puplick asked, `How many?' I agree that it is hard to estimate, but the fact is we know. We see a small portion represented in media reports and there are cases where people use multiple identities to get money out of the social security system. We know that there are hundreds of thousands of unclaimed group certificates sitting in the Australian taxation Office, and one can make a fair guess that many of those are sitting there because a person has taken a second or even a third job under a different name and does not want them all to be brought together under the one identity because then he will have to pay far more tax than he does.

What it gets down to in much of this debate is a question of whether the very mild proposal embodied in this admittedly very large piece of legislation amounts to an attack on our democratic traditions, as has been stated time and time again. As I understand it-and I may understand it a little better than the witness Senator Puplick had before him at the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card-there is no principal in either our democratic traditions or common law which allows a person fraudulently to claim a wrong identity to obtain benefits or to refuse to pay his fair contribution to the revenues by way of taxation. That is all we are talking about. Since when has dishonesty of that nature had the honourable name that should obtain some protection either by reference to some common law principal or to some democratic tradition? Of course, it never has and the Australia Card Bill is designed to try to stamp out that sort of deception.

What undermines a democracy is the deprivation of those moneys which it requires to carry out the programs which have been decided upon by the people in electing their representatives to this Parliament. If democratically elected governments are deprived of those revenues on the scale which has been put forward by the Tax Office and which could be met by the introduction of this Australia Card, and if that undermining of the revenue of government continues, that is the real attack on the sinews and very structure of our democratic way of governing ourselves in this country. Not only is there an attack on the system in that respect, but the ordinary taxpayer is, I believe, becoming somewhat disillusioned, becoming very begrudging in the moneys that he or she will make available through payment of tax to support those who genuinely need social security or Medicare support. Unless we as a parliament can demonstrate to ordinary taxpayers that we are trying to crack down on the fraudulent misuse of identity and other matters which lead to the defrauding of social security and Medicare systems, I believe that we stand in danger of taxpayers withdrawing their support for those social security and Medicare systems in a way which will then bring about once again a diminution of what we are trying to create by way of a civilised, democratic society in Australia which offers support to those genuinely in need.

I see that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has left the chamber. That is unfortunate because I wanted to bring this point to her attention. She mentioned that there could be an impact on our society such that daily demands could be made for production of the card. I wanted to quote to her clause 167 of the legislation, which states:
Except as authorised by this Act, a person shall not require another person to produce a card.
Penalty: $5,000 or imprisonment for 2 years, or both.

There one has the firmest statement that could come from this Parliament, that if an over-zealous public servant or officious policeman demanded production of the Australia Card in any situation other than is provided under this legislation-and for the ordinary average Australian, as I have pointed out, that would be on very rare occasions indeed, perhaps two or three times a year, apart from production of the Medicare card in claiming benefits under that system-we will punish that person in a very severe way, and be stating as a parliament our intention to punish in a very severe way.

The fact is that the Opposition only comes up with the old tax file number as the alternative-that is the stale old alternative which is brought up time and time again. As Senator Ryan said quite rightly, in the end even if the Opposition were correct in that matter and had its way, one would have to upgrade the tax file number to such an extent and bring about such a level of integrity by the production of documents to support the identity of a particular person with the tax file number, that one would virtually have a rose by any other name. One would virtually have everything that is required by way of the Australia Card, apart from the photograph. One would have a high integrity number identifying a particular person in the community. The fact is, as we know, that the tax file number is totally inadequate because, as the name implies, it is merely a number, attached, I suppose, in the old days to a manila folder as it travelled around the Tax Office. It bears no definite relation to a particular person in the community. It is a number which identifies a file that moves around in its manila folder. The fact that we now have computers rather than the mere physical transfer of manila folders does not diminish the force of what I am saying.

We have to find a reason for the Opposition's continuous whipping up of emotions. This urgency motion is very sanitised and talks in quite muted terms about what is wrong. Opposition members feed on the creating of hysteria and grave misgivings and real concern out in the community, by those who portray the use of this card in totally wrong and unrealistic, but nevertheless frightening, ways. I have been in Tasmania joining in the debate and I have heard of old people being frightened by claims that unless they have their Australia Card number attached to their will, it will be void and have no effect and they will die intestate. This sort of thing causes tremendous concern out in the community. Others within religious congregations have been told that the Australia Card amounts to the mark of the beast in Revelations and that it means we are on the verge of the second coming. These are very real concerns being whipped up in the community. Senator Puplick's sanitised motion is feeding off these fears and he knows that out in the community terrible distortions are taking place.

The Opposition's reasoning can be stated fairly quickly. We are getting not only at those who are involved in defrauding the social security system; we are also attacking those who are not making their proper contribution to the taxation revenues of the elected government of the day. I believe that Mr Elliott let the cat out of the bag when he said that he was quite happy with an Australia Card which merely dealt with social security fraud. That is almost a class thing. As far as he is concerned those who are unfortunate enough to be beneficiaries under the social security system can carry a card but he and his ilk certainly will not. This legislation attacks both social security fraud and those who are not paying their proper contribution to the revenues of government. Of course the Liberals and those on the other side of the chamber will always try to protect those who try to pervert the tax system. The fact that we are attacking the perversions of the tax system really rouses the ire of honourable senators opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody opposite?

—No, I am talking about the Liberals in this respect, and I think that Mr Elliott let the cat out of the bag. There is a certain unanimity between the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, which comes down to the fact that they really want to deprive the Labor Government of the sinews of government. As honourable senators know, this legislation will be a tremendous revenue raiser. The benefits will be something like $5.6 billion recouped by way of taxes and lower welfare payments over 10 years. Establishment and running costs over those 10 years will be $759m. Therefore the net benefit will be $4.6 billion over 10 years. We need those revenues in order to fulfil the programs for which we have been elected by the Australian people. In depriving us of those revenues the Opposition will force us either to go into different forms of taxation or to cut back those programs. That is a political impediment that it is trying to place in our way be depriving us of the revenues that will be obtained by the implementation of this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is clearly one of great significance to almost all Australians but its impact is still quite clearly lost on the Government. It addresses specifically the burden that the Australia Card proposal places on business and industry and the failure of the Government to prove that the Card will be cost effective. Apart from the apoplectic fulminations from the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, who is the Minister responsible, and a fairly pedestrian contribution by the Parliamentary Secretary for Justice (Senator Tate), we have had one minute-that is, the last minute of Senator Tate's speech-which addressed the revenue-raising implications. It is quite clear that revenue is the last thought on the Government's mind. It is very difficult to understand why that should be. The silence is deafening when it comes to supporters of this legislation. Two Ministers and one near Minister, who is obviously on a promise for next time, have been wheeled out today by the Government. Apart from that no one is prepared to stand up. I have been trying to organise a public meeting for October. So far I have invited Senator Tate, Senator Ryan, Mr Brumby and Senator Aulich-the latter two of course strongly espousing the Government line on the Select Committee on an Australia Card. None of them are interested any more; they have all gone to ground. It is really very sad that the Government, which professes an interest in democracy, is not prepared to recognise the overwhelming view of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the basic motivation behind this legislation we find that it was aimed at preventing losses to revenue through the tax system and through the payment of Commonwealth benefits. The four major areas targeted by the Government's proposal are taxation evasion, social security fraud, illegal immigrants and benefit protection and other areas of Commonwealth expenditure. Of course, the reality is that this proposal does nothing to address any of those areas. It is a sad reflection on the Government's supposed commitment to efficiency, to being good economic managers and to being latter day champions of privatisation. However, one has to say that the Government has very quickly gone off the boil in that regard-Telecom Australia and Australia Post are now sacrosanct and we now see that airport terminals are not going to be flogged off. Of course, it is quite clear that the Government is going to water in that area. Nonetheless, it puts itself before the people as being very concerned about the cost-benefit implications of legislation.

No doubt we will have a Budget presented to us tonight that will achieve a better Budget deficit than some commentators have suggested. That is the sort of nonsense that is usually put forward in praise of a government initiative-that somehow it is better than the commentators thought it might have been. In other words, it manages to improve on the leaked misinformation that had been put out sometime earlier. Nonetheless, that Budget will be presented tonight on the basis that somehow there are much greater revenue gains than were previously thought and therefore the Government is able to achieve a lower deficit. One of the principal reasons why it will achieve greater than expected revenue gains is the increased efficiency in the tax and social security systems, which has nothing to do with the yet to be introduced Australia Card. That in itself blows out of the water the whole notion of an Australia Card aimed at recouping all those massive escapings of Government revenue.

I will put to one side the selective squeals that we have heard to date and deal with something that has not been touched on so far-that is, the whole question of cost in this area. If one goes back prior to the formation of the Select Committee on an Australia Card, the draft White Paper on the reform of the Australian taxation system estimated that an additional tax revenue sum of some $800m would be collected from the system within a period of three years of the implementation of the Australia Card. By September of that year-in other words, some three months later-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was forced to concede that that estimate was significantly higher than was now anticipated. The Australian Taxation Office estimated that benefits would accrue of the order of $700m by the fourth full year of the system.

On the other hand, the Health Insurance Commission put out figures which were light years removed from that sort of level. It estimated that the cost benefit in total over a 10-year period on a net present value basis would be of the order of $2.4 billion. At the very same time in a submission to that Select Committee the Department of Finance, using a 10 per cent discount rate which was precisely the same approach adopted by the Tax Office, came up with a figure in excess of $3 billion. It is quite clear that the figures vary wildly and that the Government is not in a position to assess anything like the real benefits of this legislation.

This Government, which is supposedly committed to open government, still has freedom of information on the books although it makes life harder every day for those who wish to pursue it. I can announce to the chamber that James Porter will be appearing at a preliminary conference hearing next Thursday in order to obtain a copy of the Business Regulation Review Unit report. This report, which is more than 12 months old, recommended very strongly against the introduction of the Australia Card legislation on the grounds of massive costs to business. It has not yet been released by the Government despite numerous attempts to secure that release and, as I say, a FOI request which is to be dealt with at a preliminary stage. That is the sort of open government we get. The fact is that the Government is not in a position to reveal in any manner of accuracy the sorts of cost savings that will accrue because it simply does not know what they are.

If one looks at the extent to which this legislation might have any impact on the black economy, one finds that the Tax Office estimates that income tax evasion costs this community about $3 billion per annum. That is a very conservative figure, as put before Senator Aulich's Committee. The draft White Paper estimated that income tax avoidance was of the order of $1.5 billion. By putting together avoidance and evasion one arrives at a figure of $4.5 billion at the very least.

What is this sort of legislation going to do? If we are prepared to wait five or 10 years, it will recoup some hundreds of millions of dollars, apart from the massive start up costs of the order of $750m to $1,000m, which have to be paid up front. Where is the benefit in that? If the Government were serious about acting on decisions taken at tax summits and the like, it would have adopted option C and introduced a consumption tax that would have done something about the black economy, but no, here we are faced with a nebulous proposal that will do virtually nothing for the black economy. I am sure that those honourable senators who have read the Select Committee report will know precisely that: that all of the evidence demonstrated that the card simply would not achieve those sorts of gains. One of the witnesses before the Committee was Doug Meagher, QC, who is no wimp in anybody's language. He said that the ID card system would have no effect on the cash economy as moneys would simply not be put into bank accounts and would not be traceable. In the two major departmental submissions to the Joint Select Committee, the Australian Taxation Office favoured increasing the integrity of the present taxation system and the Department of Social Security pointed out that most overpayments to welfare recipients are due to departmental error or false information on income rather than falsification of identity. The Department of Social Security favoured pursuing its own automatic data processing strategic plan. The inevitable recommendation of that Committee was this:
The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC-
the Health Insurance Commission-

with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.

That report was able to come to the Australian people only by courtesy of one courageous member of the Australian Labor Party. Of course, anyone else doing the same thing now would have his membership revoked and would go the same way as former Senator Georges. Nonetheless, that is the penalty one has to pay for being truthful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Francis and Jennings.

—They got their just desserts, I can assure Senator Ray. But one cannot say the same about Mr Saunderson. I inform the Senate what he said to his colleagues. I happen to be on the mailing list for Caucus. Mr Saunderson, in his letter to all Caucus members, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The majority report, for which I take some credit in its preparation, has rejected the introduction of an ID card with or without a photograph. It did so after receiving overwhelming evidence that Tax Evasion and Social Security can be tackled successfully, using the alternate Extended Tax File System, in a cheaper and more effective manner.

If we look at the extent of tax evasion, the Tax Office by its own concessions is now getting its act together. Clearly, it needed to do that because the House of Representatives Expenditure Review Committee, reporting on five Auditor-General efficiency audits of the Tax Office, made it abundantly clear that it was not even in the game, that it was letting massive amounts of revenue go past because it did not have the resources, because it was significantly underspending on the provision that had been allocated to it. Now, of course, the Tax Office has finally and belatedly started spending something like $700m on updated computer equipment and, as a result, it is at last giving effect to the recommendations of the Auditor-General and the Expenditure Review Committee. The result of that, of course, is that it pulls the rug out from under the very proposition that we somehow need an Australia Card to catch up with tax evasion and social security fraud. It is vastly overstated in any event, but the reality is that the Tax Office is now performing very much better than it ever has in that area. It is doing the sort of job that it should have been doing quite some time ago, and it does not need any help from the un-Australian card.

I come to the cost to business. Business has an entitlement to know what it is likely to be up for. Business costs, it is estimated by the Confederation of Australian Industry, will be of the order of $377m. The Government has never provided any information to the contrary. We therefore have to assume that that is a best endeavour to assess the cost. What do the banks say about the cost to them? It would be of the order of $100m, so we thought, until the other day when the Westpac Banking Corporation came out and said that 64,000 customers may well need to have spent on them about $5 per account. That amounts to $300m. That is the sort of cost to industry that we are talking about. Who is that going to be passed on to? It will be passed on to the taxpayers who are supposedly to benefit from this iniquitous legislation.

It is clear that the benefits do not add up at all. The proposals that are envisaged are clearly short-sighted, have been blown out of the water and are being pursued only because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is still sufficiently ego-obsessed that he is not prepared to back down in the face of overwhelming community opposition. Even his State Premiers are not prepared to stand up and be counted. Mr Cain must have a very painful and tender private region from the amount of time he has spent sitting on the fence in recent weeks. Mr Bannon has said that he is not prepared to make the register of births, deaths and marriages available until he knows how much money is going to be reimbursed to the State Government. Mr Unsworth, of course, wants to call the whole deal off, and we know that the Premier of Queensland will not have a bar of the system.

What sort of an arrangement is that going to be? It is quite clear that it is going to be ineffective and unworkable. But, more importantly, the costs of the system are going to be all one way. There are not going to be any benefits. Indeed the Prime Minister, in his address to the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress, went so far as to put forward this master of equivocation. He estimated that the benefits of the Australia Card would ultimately be $900m per annum. He then went on to say, as have Senator Ryan and Dr Blewett, that the Government was losing $2.5m a day for every day that the Australia Card legislation was not introduced. If we do our sums, we see that the current figure would be $1.3m. Do honourable senators know how the Government gets to the $2.5m figure? It says that if we go to a 10 year period that is when it will start costing $2.5m, and that we can somehow bring that figure forward to today. It is a nonsense and it is a ludicrous proposition. It is quite clear that it is a desperate attempt by the Government somehow to try to shame its supporters into standing up and supporting this legislation.

I am afraid the game is up. It is quite clear that the Prime Minister is only waiting until a convenient time to withdraw this legislation, probably around Christmas when the Parliament has risen. Until then we are going to have to put up with the time of this Parliament being wasted on debating what is clearly a totally ineffective and useless piece of legislation which will not achieve any of its objective, which the Government is not prepared to address sensibly in terms of the cost benefit implications, which ultimately has no mandate at all and was not even given a guernsey during the election campaign and the benefits of which clearly do not leave much of an impact on the Prime Minister's mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating an urgency motion which has been put down today, the first working day of the new parliament after an election, which followed a double dissolution because the Senate refused on two occasions to pass legislation to deal with the Australia Card. It is passing strange that this first debate is on the very issue which led to the dissolution of the Senate and the House of Representatives. I thought the Opposition would have less shame than that, but obviously that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the debate is about the Australia Card, let me put a direct challenge to all of those who have spoken in this debate in opposition to the Government. My challenge is: `Put your plastic on the table. Show us whether you have a Mastercard. Put down your Visa card. Show us whether you have a Diners Club card. Produce your American Express card'. By seeking consumer credit have we not voluntarily given all the details and more that the Opposition complains the Government might have-but in fact which it will not have-not to the Government but to private organisations with controls which the Opposition complains the Government might have in that position? Those opposite have no idea what sorts of controls over information they have given up to private organisations, yet they come in here and criticise the Government for trying to establish a high integrity identification system which is, as best it can be devised, foolproof from hackers, foolproof in terms of the penalties and other technological restraints on the system and foolproof from being in any way abused. I bet that all those who have spoken in this debate have some sort of credit and that much more information is available about them-and they pretend it is a matter of privacy. If they do not have any credit cards, they do of course have a Medicare card. One of the functions that an Australia Card will perform is to rationalise the Medicare system and help it to operate more effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to the people of Victoria. Tell that to the surgeons in New South Wales. That is precisely the problem.
—Order! Senator Haines, there are too many interjections.

—Mr Deputy President, Senator Haines is not troubling me one wit with her interjections. I will deal later with what she said. Let me go back to the beginning of this debate. The Senate has twice debated the legislation that will shortly be presented to it so that it can again debate the Australia Card. It has conducted an inquiry which brought down a majority decision and reported it here. The Parliament was dissolved prior to the election, and the people of Australia had a chance during the election campaign to express a view on the matter. We are on the Government side; members of the coalition are on the Opposition side. It seems that we won the election. In expressing a view the people of Australia have returned us, not them.

SPEECH.PARA: In the dying throes of Senator Alston's speech he said that the Australia Card would have been an election issue had it been given a chance, or words to that effect. Let us deal with that matter because there are motions on notice in the Senate suggesting that there should be a referendum. We have just had an election but the Opposition now wants a referendum. Why did the Opposition not take advantage of the democratic processes laid down by the Australian Constitution and argue in the election campaign the issues about which it now claims to have some conscientious view?

Anyone who saw the 7.30 Report last week would have seen an interview conducted by Paul Lyneham with some of the doyens of the parliamentary Press Gallery in Canberra. Paul Lyneham put this question to the Gallery journalists:
Was the Australia Card raised as a serious issue for debate during the campaign by either side?

Let us see what the Gallery said about that. If members of the Press have been cited as impartial umpires in this debate, which I have never accepted they were, let us see what the direct observers of this process had to say. Michelle Gratton of the Age stated:

I think it was a minor issue, I think the government was quite happy to talk about it because it felt that certainly at that stage it was quite a popular issue but I think it was just overwhelmed by other issues.
Michelle Gratton recognised that we certainly talked about the matter; we never hid our light under a bushel. Laurie Oakes said:

It was certainly raised by the government, I remember the first of the Labor Party newspaper ads was about the I.D. Card. It had four photographs of the card and in Hawke's speech in Adelaide, where a bloke threw himself in front of the car that got all the headlines, but that speech was primarily about the Australia Card and the Senate.
Oakes continued:
So Labor raised it but the Opposition certainly didn't because their research showed that it wasn't an issue and they let the chance go.
What did Geoff Kitney of the Times on Sunday say? He talked about his newspaper's efforts to raise the matter and stated:
. . . largely because John Howard didn't have his heart in it. In fact John Howard, when they first proposed the idea, was in favour of an I.D. card.
What did Kerry O'Brien of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation say? He said that the Opposition did not raise it; it let it go. Gregory Hywood of the Australian Financial Review said:
The government triggered the double dissolution on it. The Opposition obviously didn't feel it was enough of a vote winner to raise in the campaign.
What did Mike Steketee of the Sydney Morning Herald say? He said:

I think John Howard said after the election when this was raised with him-why didn't you make more of an issue of it-he said. I wanted to concentrate peoples attention on tax and there's a limited number of things that you can get people to focus on.

He wanted to concentrate people's attention on the fraudulent effort to pretend that he could buy votes in Australia by cutting taxes, selling off everything and operating voodoo economics to try to swindle Australian voters into believing that he could do miracles, which was not true. The interviewer on the 7.30 Report turned to Mr Howard and asked:
Mr Howard, thanks for joining us. With the benefit of hindsight, could you have done more with the Australia Card as an election issue?

What did John Howard say to that? This is the first issue the Liberal Party has put down for debate in the new Parliament; this is the one issue which the Liberal Party has tacked its banner to the masthead to go into battle over. What did Mr Howard say when asked why he did not make the Australia Card an issue during the election campaign? He said:
Well we could have but I don't regret the priority I gave to certain issues in the campaign . . . I don't regret the priority that I gave to other issues.

Was John Howard fair dinkum and can we expect the Opposition to be fair dinkum now? The answer is that those who talk about a referendum had their chance during the election campaign. They know the Constitution and the parliamentary process. They blew it and they are now trying to regurgitate a campaign which, I suggest, is based mostly on a motion, primarily on fear, and fundamentally on a misrepresentation of the facts in order to gull Australian electors into believing that something will happen to their privacy which will not happen and which is not intended. In any case, if they volunteer to take consumer credit, they are open to risks that this high integrity system is absolutely not open to.

Before I leave the Liberal Party, there is one other person in the Liberal Party who ought to get a run in this debate but who has not been mentioned. He deserves to be given a go: John Elliott, the aspirant President of the Liberal Party and its former treasurer, a person who sometimes goes abroad and shafts the Australian economy to foreign audiences-the so-called possible future Leader of the Liberal Party. What is John Elliott's view about the Australia Card? Emphatically he does not have an in-principle objection to it. All he says is that certain people should be required to have it. Who are those people? They are only those on welfare, that is, only those citizens in this country who are poor, only those in unfortunate economic circumstances. He does not have a principled objection to the idea as long as the poor are made to have the card. I ask John Howard: Why, when this card is directed at tax avoiders as much as it is at welfare fraud, does he not want those who pay tax and have the option of defrauding the tax base in this country to have the card? That may or may not be a question which John Elliott will answer.

Some of us sat through the arguments in the Senate about bottom of the harbour tax avoidance in the 1983 sessions and in 1984 when this Government put two Bills before this Parliament in order to stamp it out. Which parties voted down those Bills? The Government introduced them but who knocked them off? It was the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Democrats. If a government is to stamp out tax avoidance of the sort that the Government aimed at, it needs the capacity, once it has identified a fraudulent taxation system, to retrospectively recover the ill-gotten gains that those who have been operating that system have acquired. If a government has that ability, there is absolutely no incentive for people to engage in tax avoidance. Who denied this Government that ability? It was the Liberal Party, the National Party and some-not all-of the Democrats. Some of them had principles, stuck with us and voted for the proposition. We hear arguments in this chamber that those opposite really are opposed to tax avoidance and that we should look at the record to decide not what they say but what they do and take what they do as a guide to what they may do in the future, but the record on tax avoidance is very patchy. Unfortunately, some of my friends in the Australian Democrats are subject to that allegation just as much as those in the Liberal Party and National Party.

How did we get into the question of the Australia Card in the first place? We won government in 1983 because there were widespread tax rorts and tax ramps in this country. The people of Australia disbelieved and regarded as non-credible any fundamental conviction that a Liberal government would do anything about them. They elected a Labor government to clean up the tax base of this country. We have done that. In 1985, after being returned to office for the second time, we published a White Paper on tax reform. Options A, B and C all proposed an Australia Card. We had a National Economic Summit. No one can say that there has not been enough debate. The debate has been raging backwards and forwards since 1985. The Australia Card was part of our fundamental commitment on coming to power in 1983. It survived the election in 1984. We have been returned again in 1987. No one can say that there has not been adequate debate on the issue. No one in this chamber can say that there has not been adequate debate, except those new senators who have just joined us. We welcome them to our ranks. They will hear the debate pretty soon. We have had the Bill here twice before and argued every single stitch and clause of it. It will be back here again soon and the new senators will have their opportunity to take part in the debate then.

The other point I want to make before my time expires is that I am fundamentally, as is Neal Blewett and Susan Ryan-the two Ministers who have carriage of the card-and as is the Australian Labor Party, committed to the protection of civil liberties in this country. We are a party with that record of protection. We are a party that is believed by the constituents of this country to stand for those things. I do not say that because we are believed to stand for them we can rest on our laurels. In this sort of an issue one has to prove one's achievements every day and every hour of every day all the time. Civil liberties are a delicate question that constantly requires defence.

But when the articulate middle class in this country raises the question of our civil liberties I want to pose the question on behalf of the poor and on behalf of people who rely on welfare: What about their civil liberties? By holding up the introduction of this card, the Opposition is denying $4.7 billion which it will net in real government revenue over 10 years. That is money this Government can use to improve the situation of people in real need. Who speaks for them? The articulate middle class, with their Visa Cards in their hip pockets who have surrendered all their information to the privately controlled privacy banks, do not speak for them. Who speaks for them? They are entitled to say: `We want more out of this economy. We want an end to tax fraud. We want an end to welfare fraud. We want a bit more of the revenue base that goes to government because we are the people in real need'. The Labor Party speaks for them. That is why this urgency motion should be defeated today.

The second point I make in relation to what Senator Cook has had to say is that if there has been adequate debate, what does he say about the fact that Ministers in his Government admit that this legislation needs amendment and that we are not going to be given the opportunity to debate the amendments which the Government itself accepts are correct and proper and which ought to be made?

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the matters raised by Senator Ryan. Senator Ryan says quite glibly that there may have been leaks from the Health Insurance Commission. She is not prepared to do anything about that. Her Government is not prepared to do anything about it. When she makes claims that there are thousands of fraudulent people in the community, let her and let her Government explain why Senator Tate and his Department are deliberately suppressing the report by the Australian Federal Police on fraud against the Commonwealth.

I come to Senator Tate. Senator Tate says that it will not be necessary to produce the card perhaps more than three or four times a year for most people in the community. If he is telling the truth he will have to admit that, for instance, if one employs a babysitter once a week one will have to obtain the Australia Card number of that babysitter. The same applies to somebody who might do one's gardening, cleaning work or whatever. Every one of those transactions will require one to obtain the Australia Card number. I can understand why Senator Tate might not understand these matters, but the Australia Card legislation requires a person to obtain the Australia Card number of the individuals concerned in such transactions, to record them and to report them to the Australian Taxation Office. The idea that one might have to have the Australia Card produced for such purposes only three or four times a year is absolutely spurious.

I believe that our case in this urgency debate has been adequately made out by speakers on this side of the Parliament, particularly by Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Alston. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, because of the late commencement of the sittings-which in turn was occasioned by the mid-year election, which is an unusual time to have an election and which was of the Government's making of course, and not of the Opposition's-has set a series of sitting dates for the Parliament which are extremely intensive. I wish to record at this stage the Opposition's concern about the length of sittings which are being imposed. Under this Government the Parliament moved some time ago to a two weeks on, two weeks off, back-to-back sitting pattern, which was in part brought in to assist people such as Senator Collins, and honourable senators from Western Australia and Queensland, who have long distances to travel.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that was entered into in very good faith by the Parliament as an attempt to find a more satisfactory pattern of sittings. Whilst the two weeks on, two weeks off is the theory, we are sitting for three weeks at a time with one week up. The Government is proposing to have sittings of Estimates committees in one of those weeks when the Parliament is not sitting. I think that the pressure not only on the Opposition but also on the Ministers and on the members of parliament generally is very unreasonable. It is likely to lead not only to bad behaviour in this place but also to the deterioration of senators' and members' health.

I do no more than express my concern about that. The Opposition has for the last 4 1/2 years accepted the obligation to sit when the Government has requested that we should do so, but I believe that the sitting pattern which has been adopted is most unwise, and I ask the Government, in looking at the sitting pattern next year-bearing in mind no doubt that it will be arranging considerable festivities during that year-to try to arrange a more manageable sitting pattern for the sake of everybody who serves in this Parliament.

I give the Government notice that the Opposition will be seeking a variation in the proposal for the sitting of Estimates committees because it does not believe that it is reasonable that in the very brief periods we are not sitting we are required to come back to do Estimates committees. DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTERS OF STATE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987ADMINISTRATIVE ARRANGEMENTS BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bills be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Ministers of State Act 1952 and a Bill for an Act to amend the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the Public Service Act 1922 in connection with certain administrative arrangements, and for related purposes.
