SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
MINISTERS OF STATE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

The Ministers of State Act currently provides that there can be no more than 27 Ministers. As announced by the Prime Minister on 14 July, the Government wishes to have a Ministry of 30, administering 18 Departments in place of the previous 28.
The total cost of Ministerial remuneration (salary and expenses of office allowance) in a full year would be $97,752.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
ADMINISTRATIVE ARRANGEMENTS BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend two Acts: the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, to clarify the scope of existing provisions of that Act in the light of the recent changes to Ministerial and Departmental structures; and the Public Service Act 1922, to abolish the Public Service Board and establish new arrangements in its place. A separate Bill will be introduced to amend the Ministers of State Act 1952, to increase from 27 to 30 the number of Ministers who may be appointed.
Administrative Arrangements Legislation

As a result of the Prime Minister's announcement of the introduction of revised arrangements for the administration by Ministers of Departments, it is desirable to clarify provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act relating to the meaning of references in legislation to Ministers and Departments. In particular, the amendments deal with situations where a Minister administers two or more Departments or where a single Department is administered by two or more Ministers. While the existing provisions of the Act are capable of application to the new arrangements, it is obviously desirable to put the matter beyond doubt and also to deal with the particular features of the new arrangements.
The Treasurer, in the May Economic Statement, announced that the existing structure of the Public Service Board was under review.

Since then, the Prime Minister has accepted a recommendation from Mr David Block, in his capacity as head of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit, that the Public Service Board be abolished. The amendments before the Senate repeal provisions of the Public Service Act establishing the Public Service Board and substitute provisions establishing an office of Public Service Commissioner. Further legislation will be prepared to give full effect to the Government's proposals for the distribution of the Board's powers. In the meantime the Bill provides for the continuation of the existing delegations of the Board's powers and functions to related management agencies, for example, the Department of Industrial Relations, and to Secretaries of departments generally.

The Bill also provides for the establishment of an Australian Public Service Management Advisory Board comprising part-time members who will include the Commissioner, the Secretaries of certain departments, a person with a trade union background and a person with private sector experience. The new body's functions will include the provision of advice to the Government on significant issues relating to the management of the Australian Public Service.
The Bill includes a number of consequential and transitional provisions.
It is estimated that the abolition of the Public Service Board will save approximately $8 million in 1987/88 and $16.5 million in 1988/89.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

It is now some three and a half years since the introduction of legislation to provide the Australian National Railways Commission (AN) with a charter which gave AN the task of becoming a commercially oriented business operation.
In the previous year, AN had recorded its highest ever loss of $106 million. Since then, AN has made considerable progress.

This progress reflects this Government's approach of creating an environment in which its business authorities can get on with the job of improving their performance. In real terms AN's call on the Federal Budget has been reduced by over 60% during this period.
It is a record in which everyone associated with AN, the Chairman, Commissioners, AN management, Unions and AN workforce can take pride.

But we cannot stop there. Accordingly this Government is continuing to work with AN, and its staff to maintain that momentum which will lead AN to become a genuinely commercially viable Government railway.

As part of this continuing drive for improved efficiency, on 1 October 1986 the former Minister for Transport the Hon Peter Morris, MP, announced a package of further initiatives including a new approach to AN's passenger services.

The fact is that like virtually every railway in the world AN's passenger services are not currently commercially viable. However, with operational and marketing initiatives, their future prospects are improved.

While AN's performance is better than many of the other Australian rail systems, particularly for its long distance services, there is room to achieve greater efficiency. The Government and AN are embarking upon the demanding approach of upgrading these services rather than allowing them to drift into a state where they are beyond redemption.

We have agreed with AN a set of increasing cost recovery targets to be achieved in respect of these passenger services. From a level of around 45% in 1984-85 AN now has the task of improving its passenger cost recovery level to a 60% target by 1988-89.
AN has already launched a number of major initiatives to provide better, more efficient services to its customers. These include
upgrading the Mount Gambier service with improved transit times and on-board service which has resulted in a 15% increase in patronage

the Launching in 1986 of a new Adelaide-Whyalla Budd car service which replaced the Adelaide-Port Pirie service. This service, known as the Iron Triangle Limited, is currently running at almost full capacity
diversion of the Indian Pacific into Adelaide in 1986 without adding to the total journey time
the launching of a new service, known as the Silver City Limited between Adelaide and Broken Hill in December 1986
launching of a conference car on the Ghan to cater for business functions.
AN considers that it should further extend the facilities it provides to its passengers to make train travel a far more enjoyable experience in itself.
Accordingly it has refurbished rollingstock to provide a special entertainment car, offering facilities such as
video and sound booths
video games for children
tables for cards and chess
a souvenir shop
a hair salon
a limited number of poker machines.
To provide a clear legislative base for these activities it is necessary for the amendments contained in section 3 of this Bill to be enacted.
AN has consulted both the South Australian and Northern Territory governments on the proposal and both Governments have raised no objections.
The second amendment incorporated in the Bill will preserve the existing workers compensation entitlements for AN employees who were transferred from the South Australian Railways in 1978.

A condition of the transfer was that these employees would have the option of claiming compensation benefits under either the South Australian or Federal provisions. This was embodied in Section 47 of the ANRC Act 1983.

However, the existing South Australian Act is to be repealed on 1 October 1987. This means those employees would lose their right to claim compensation under South Australian law. In view of the Government's commitments at the time of transfer, it is only proper that the Government should continue to honour those commitments. This amendment will ensure that the right to choose between the current SA provisions and Federal provisions is maintained.
The third provision of the Bill will amend Section 70 of the Act to expand the powers under which Boards of Inquiry undertake investigations into the causes of accidents involving AN.
Two Boards of Inquiry have been established under the Act. They have proven to be extremely valuable in having an independent body examine major accidents.

It is considered that future inquiries would benefit by having wider powers to allow them to consider the broader causes of accidents. The proposed powers are similar to provisions governing accident enquiries under the Air Navigation Regulations.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, and for related purposes.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is unchanged from the form in which it was passed by the House of Representatives on 26 February 1987, and the form in which it was introduced into this House on 17 March 1987.

The Bill makes some fine-tuning amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. As many honourable members will no doubt know, this Act, which came into operation on 1 October 1980, codified and modernised the ancient prerogative writ remedies under which the lawfulness of government decision making could be challenged. The Act streamlined the procedures under which citizens could challenge, on legal grounds, administrative decisions and it did away with technicalities that applied under the old remedies. This innovative legislation has thus been in operation for some seven years and it is now an appropriate time to be examining the Act to see where improvements can be made.

A particular concern has been the use made of the Act in the course of administrative proceedings before some other tribunal in circumstances where the particular decision can be challenged at the conclusion of those administrative proceedings. Recourse to the Federal Court under the Act in the course of the administrative proceeding, rather than assisting in the dispatch of business of that tribunal, can have quite the opposite effect. It can frustrate and delay the proper decision making processes of the tribunal. We are all aware of the events which surrounded the hearings of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal into the granting of a third commercial television licence for Perth in which, in the course of these proceedings, 16 cases were decided by the Federal Court under the Act. The effect of all this litigation was to delay the decision of the Tribunal on the third licence for some 12 months.

The Bill will facilitate the efficient operation of administrative tribunals, authorities and persons by minimising the disruption caused by the making of applications under the Act in the course of proceedings. Clause 2 of the Bill provides that where an application for review is lodged in relation to a decision made by a tribunal, authority or persons during those proceedings and a review of that decision is available at the conclusion of those proceedings, and it is desirable to avoid interference with those proceedings, the Court shall refuse to grant the application unless the Court is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice for the application to be granted.

Another area of concern is where overlapping remedies are available. For example, in Public Service discipline matters, a person is able to appeal to a Public Service disciplinary appeal body, which can review the whole case. The person can also test the lawfulness but not the merits of the decision under the Act. The Act at present gives the Court a general discretion to refuse an application where there is another remedy available. The Government considers that some strengthening of this provision is desirable.

The Bill does not remove any existing rights of review, but seeks to rationalise those instances where there exist overlapping remedies by encouraging applicants, where review is provided for under some other law, to avail themselves of that alternative review before seeking review under the Act. Review by means other than by recourse to the Act is often a more cost and time effective means of obtaining proper review of an administrative decision.

Clause 2 of the Bill therefore amends section 10 of the Act by inserting a new paragraph 10 (2) (c). That paragraph provides that where an application for review is lodged with the Federal Court under the Act, and provision is made by any law other than the Act under which the applicant is entitled to seek a review of that decision otherwise than by a court-the Court shall refuse to grant the application unless it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice for the Court to grant the application. This latter qualification recognises that there may be cases where the Court should hear the application, notwithstanding the existence of an alternative remedy.

The Bill also makes express provision for the Court to refuse to grant an application for review, or to stay an application where it considers it inappropriate to grant the application or continue the proceedings. This gives statutory expression to the Court's present wide discretion to refuse relief and in addition makes it clear that this discretion extends to enabling the Court to stay proceedings in appropriate cases.

The Bill is intended to ensure these powers conferred on the Court are exercised in such a way that costs and delays are kept to a minimum and to this end the Bill provides that these powers be exercised at the earliest appropriate stage in the course of proceedings.

Whilst the revenue implications of these proposals are not quantifiable, the measure should result in fewer hearings under the Act, and thus will have an impact on the Court's workload. By minimising the disruption to hearings it should also aid the efficiency of Tribunals. This will result in revenue savings.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act relating to bankruptcy.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1987 marks a major turning point in the administration of bankruptcy law in this country. The amendments proposed by the Bill have been developed in response to:
The Costigan Royal Commission finding that bankruptcy laws were being abused by fraudulently motivated insolvency claims;
The Government's commitment to sensible and considered law reform; and
The need for modern bankruptcy law to attack insolvency fraud while also providing appropriate protection for those whose bankruptcy is caused through misfortune.

Honourable senators will recall that the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 2) 1986 amended the Bankruptcy Act in a number of ways, including significant changes to the administrative powers and functions of the official trustee. This Bill takes that process one step further by implementing Mr Costigan's recommendation that the trustee in bankruptcy should be equipped with wider powers of investigation in order to combat insolvency fraud.
The Bill amends the Act in three significant areas by:
extending the investigative powers of the trustee;
reforming Part X of the Act and introducing a prebankruptcy moratorium period; and
modernizing the Act in relation to spouses' claims and the retention of personal transport.
INSOLVENCY FRAUD

It has been recognized for many years that the duty of the trustee in bankruptcy is twofold: to realise the debtor's property and distribute the proceeds amongst creditors and also to protect the public interest by investigating a bankrupt's conduct with a view to upholding standards of commercial morality.

The powers which the Bankruptcy Act presently gives the trustee to facilitate the discharge of this duty have not kept pace with the wider use of modern commercial structures of companies and trusts. The trustee's ability to investigate companies and trusts associated with the bankrupt is severely circumscribed. For example, a bankrupt who is being examined on oath cannot be asked questions as to any actions he took in his capacity as managing director of a number of companies. Such limits on the trustee's powers have opened the way for unscrupulous debtors to defeat the aims of the bankruptcy law. By using a plethora of family trusts and companies, debtors have been able to organize their affairs so that they are apparently without any assets, while they continue to enjoy the use of property and assets which have the guise of being owned by a company or trust. Practices such as ``remuneration skimming'', which put assets of companies or trusts associated with a debtor beyond the trustee or creditors, fall into this category.

As well, provisions which presently limit which property of a bankrupt may be realized by the trustees exacerbate the problems. In broad terms, only that property in which the bankrupt had a beneficial interest at the date of the bankruptcy is available to the creditors. These provisions are ineffective to deal with ``remuneration skimming''.

This Bill proposes to deal with these problems by extending the trustee's powers to investigate the bankrupt's affairs and by enabling the trustee to recoup from companies, partnerships, trusts and other persons, assets which have been acquired by the personal efforts of the bankrupt. The Bill will introduce related concepts of ``associated entities'' and ``examinable affairs'' and a proposed division 4A of part VI which will enable a court to make orders in relation to the property of entities controlled by a bankrupt.

An associated entity will be one which the bankrupt is able to influence by virtue of close business or family relationships or which is under the control of the bankrupt. The examinable affairs of the bankrupt which the trustee will be able to investigate will be included to include the power to investigate the financial affairs of an entity associated with the bankrupt insofar as those financial affairs are relevant to the bankrupt's financial affairs. This will be in addition to the existing powers of a trustee to investigate the conduct, dealings and transactions of the bankrupt himself. Associated entities will be placed under an obligation to cooperate with the trustee by making books of account and financial records available where this will assist in shedding light on the bankrupt's financial affairs.

The extension of the powers of the trustee to investigate all the circumstances surrounding a bankruptcy is of itself not enough if at the end of the day no real benefit will flow through to the creditors. Accordingly the court is to be empowered, on application of the trustee, to transfer specified property of an entity to the trustee, or to order the payment to the trustee of a sum of money representing the amount by which the net value of the entity has been enhanced, where the trustee establishes:
that the entity acquired the property or the entity's asset position was enhanced during the ``examinable period'';
during the examinable period, the bankrupt supplied personal services to the entity in accordance with the bankrupt's direction, wishes or instructions; and

the entity made property available or would in the future, make property available for the use and enjoyment of the bankrupt in accordance with his or her wishes or instructions, as if the property actually belonged to the bankrupt.

There are a number of provisions requiring the court to take account of the interests of third parties who have an interest in property of the entity, and creditors of the entity. The Government is confident that the new division 4A of part VI will be an effective weapon in stamping out insolvency fraud.
PREBANKRUPTCY MORATORIUM

The Government recognizes that bankruptcy is and must be a remedy of last resort. While an insolvent person must be able to obtain relief from his or her creditors, people should be encouraged to explore the alternatives to bankruptcy which are available. Those alternatives include the three forms of voluntary arrangement available under part X-a Deed of Arrangement, a Deed of Assignment, or a composition-or by an informal repayment scheme. These alternatives all involve consultation between a debtor and creditors and accordingly they usually proceed in a more co-operative fashion than bankruptcy.

The introduction of a prebankruptcy moratorium period will allow a debtor to consider the alternatives to bankruptcy. Under a new division 2A of part IV, a debtor will be able to present to the registrar in bankruptcy a declaration of intention to present a debtor's petition. Once this declaration is accepted by the registrar, the debtor will be able to invoke a limited stay upon certain debt recovery processes for a maximum period of 7 days. The registrar will be obliged to direct the debtor's attention to the sources of advice and guidance with respect to the debtor's financial affairs, and to the procedures under the Bankruptcy Act for dealing with insolvency.
REFORM OF PART X

At the same time the Government is aware that there are flaws in Part X which have been exploited by a small number of unscrupulous trustees and solicitors in order to defraud the creditors. The Government has therefore moved quickly to include a group of amendments to Part X to minimise the facility for abuse of its procedures.

The Government has identified three particular problems with the procedures set out in Part X. First, creditors do not receive sufficient information about a debtors affairs before they accept arrangements under Part X. Secondly there are no provisions in the Act which ensure that previous dealings between a debtor, a particular creditor or creditors and the trustee are disclosed. Thirdly there is no effective supervision of Part X arrangements.

This Bill addresses the first of these three problems by requiring a debtor to submit a statement of affairs at the commencement of the process, rather than at the first meeting of creditors. At present, under Part X a debtor may execute an authority to authorise a registered trustee to take control of their property or a solicitor to call a meeting of their creditors. This Bill will require this authority to be supported by a recently prepared statement of affairs which has been given to the trustee or solicitor. The trustee will be required to prepare a report on the debtors affairs and indicate in that report which of the alternative modes of administration-Deed of Assignment, Deed of Arrangement or Composition would be in the best interests of creditors.

The trustee will also be required to indicate whether or not the creditors should accept a Part X arrangement or require the debtor to present a bankruptcy petition. A registered trustee or solicitor will also be required to prepare a statement setting out the alternative special resolutions that may be passed by a meeting of creditors namely, that the debtor execute a deed of assignment or a deed of arrangement, that the creditors accept a composition or that the debtor present a debtor's petition within 7 days of the day on which the resolution is passed. The report by the controlling trustee and the statement outlining the alternative special resolutions which creditors may pass at the meeting are required to be circulated, with notice of the meeting by the controlling trustee or solicitor.
These measures are completed by changes to the proxy provisions relating to voting at meetings under Part X.

In relation to the second problem of ensuring that prior dealings between debtors, creditors and trustees are fully disclosed, a new provision is to be inserted into the Act so that a resolution purporting to nominate or appoint a registered trustee to a particular trusteeship will be deemed not to have been duly passed unless the registered trustee has consented to the nomination and has made a declaration concerning his or her professional, business or personal relationship or connexion, if any, with the debtor or the creditor who proposed the resolution.

To overcome the third problem-the inadequacy of the supervisory power in relation to Part X arrangements-the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy is to be given the right to apply to the court for orders setting aside deeds and compositions. The Inspector-General will also be empowered to apply to the court for an order that a trustee make good any loss that is caused by a breach of duty by the trustee, and for orders cancelling or suspending the registration of the person as a trustee. Where the court makes an order cancelling the registration of the person as trustee, the bond into which the person entered as a condition of becoming registered will be able to be called in. In another significant change in this area, examinations of registered trustees will now be conducted before a registrar, rather than before a court. These changes will continue the reforms of administration of the Bankruptcy Act which are designed to free up judicial resources to enable them to be used in the resolution of more important disputes.
MODERNIZING THE ACT

Numerous other important reforms to modernize the Bankruptcy Act are introduced by this Bill. Section 111-`postponement of spouse's claims'-is to be repealed. In addition, the provision whereby certain property of the non-bankrupt spouse which had been `made available to or lent to' the now bankrupt spouse was expropriated and made available to the creditors will be repealed.

Subsection 116 (2) will be amended by including in the category of property not available to the trustee, a motor vehicle or other form of personal transport to the modest value of $2500. Typically, creditors get little or no benefit from the sale of motor vehicles and this action places considerable hardship on the bankrupt and his family.
SUMMARY

The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill will introduce significant changes to the Bankruptcy Legislation which will greatly improve the administration of insolvencies in the future. The amendments will, on the one hand, ensure that trustees in bankruptcy can investigate sophisticated commercial arrangements which have used the bankruptcy laws to defraud creditors. On the other hand, in recognition that bankruptcy is not the most appropriate solution in all circumstances, the Bill also introduces procedures to encourage debtors to consider possible alternatives to bankruptcy in appropriate circumstances and introduces reforms to Part X to ensure that these alternative procedures can be of real benefit to both debtors and creditors.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT

The amendments proposed by the Bill will not involve any additional financial impact upon Government expenditure. Following the restructuring of the official trustee to which I referred earlier, the resources necessary to discharge the wider investigatory powers conferred by these amendments will be available within the official Trustee Corporation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to establish the Defence Housing Authority. This Bill is substantially the same as the Bill that was received from the House of Representatives and introduced into the Senate by the then Minister representing the Minister for Defence, Senator Evans, on 30 April 1987. The earlier Bill lapsed with the dissolution of the last parliament.

In his second reading speech, Senator Evans made it clear that the proposed legislation is the cornerstone of the government's strategy to provide adequate accommodation for members of the defence force.

In view of the pressure of parliamentary time during this period of sittings, I do not propose to repeat the previous speech. However, in commending it to honourable members, I would like to emphasise the following points:
The Defence Housing Authority will implement the Government's obligation to ensure that members of the Defence Force are ad- equately housed;
The Authority will operate with commercial freedom consistent with meeting the housing needs of the Defence Force;
The Authority, in charging the Department of Defence full commercial rents, will have a guaranteed level of income;
The level of rent paid by individual service tenants will, however, continue to be determined by the government as a condition of service;

Within overall Budget priorities, it is the Government's intention to have $750m committed to Defence Housing capital outlays over the next decade. To the extent that its income is insufficient, the Defence Housing Authority will be able to seek supplementary funding to achieve this objective;

The financial impact of the Bill is set out in the accompanying explanatory memorandum. The authority will use its profits for capital acquisition and improvements so demands for capital from the Budget ($65.8m in 1986/87) will be reduced. PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Puplick for Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act relating to the submission to the electors of a question in relation to the introduction of the Australia Card.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
I present the second reading on my private members Bill titled the ``Australia Card Referendum Act 1987'' designed to submit the ultimate decision on the Australia Card to the people of Australia.

Currently there is an Act in existence to regulate referenda on proposed amendments of the Constitution. This is the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. I have followed the procedure laid down in this Act, and indeed incorporates that Act, with modifications, and applies it to the proposed Referendum.

I have provided for the Referendum to be decided by a majority of votes cast. I have not followed the special provision for amending the constitution where majorities in a Majority of States are also required.

This is because the legislation concerned is fundamentally a Commonwealth law which does not effect any changes to the Constitution or to the consequent legal rights or position of the States in our Federation. As a purely Commonwealth law it should be put to and decided upon by all the people in their capacity as Commonwealth electors, on a truely national basis.
I now turn to the reasons why I have presented this Bill. Why the people must decide on the so-called Australia Card legislation, which could so gravely impact on their lives and liberties.
INVASION OF PRIVACY

Today, personal and confidential information is listed under many numbers-Credit Cards, Medicare Cards, Tax File and Social Security number. This multiplicity of unlinked and unmatched numbers is a protection which will be removed by the ID Card. After the Card is introduced one single number will be the key to all personal and confidential information.

Furthermore, it will be obligatory for all individuals to provide this number to banks, employers, real estate agents, stock and station agents, produce merchants, share brokers and Medicare, Social Security and the Tax Office. Quite clearly, persons with illegal intent will have little difficulty obtaining other peoples numbers and, as the newspapers record every week, getting inside a computer, however sophisticated, is not difficult, all that is needed is the number. No one can guarantee the security of computer records.
You must give a prospective employer the same number which can access your medical records-a matter of great interest to employers in these days of workers compensation abuse.

Your bank accounts will bear the same number as your accounts at the real estate agent or stock firm-and so on-and whilst I do not suggest that every employer or banker would choose to cross reference such vital information, it is certain that the opportunity to do so is greatly improved by this single numbering process.

The Government claims that the only information that is accessed by the card is the details of your birth, address and such. The legislation refers specifically to this ``register'' but by requiring production of the card to all the other instrumentalities I have mentioned it guarantees that your card number is the common factor in linking of this information for government purposes and their computers will be linked by telecom line; government departments are notorious for their leaks.
People may have nothing to hide but may have legitimate secrets they are entitled to keep.
The card will deny you any privacy.
INCONVENIENCE
If you have done nothing wrong and probably pay your tax through P.A.Y.E., why should you suffer the following inconvenience?
1. Queuing to be numbered and photographed. $500 fines if you then lose the card in certain circumstances.

2. Attending personally at the bank to validate your bank accounts with your ID number. The account will be frozen if not so validated by a certain date. There are 64 million accounts to be revalidated.

3. Sporting, social and service clubs will also be required to have a card number and the incumbent secretary or treasurer must carry the card in their name, meaning more queuing and paperwork every time you change office bearers.
4. You must appear personally at the real estate agent and registrar of titles with the card to effect a sale of your home. So must the purchaser.
5. Father and son, or other individuals must exchange card numbers to conclude a family loan and report the transaction to the tax man.
6. Farmers and/or people dealing in shares will not buy and sell through agents without producing their card.
Mr Keating, however, will not need one to buy or sell antiques.

You will not initiate most new business without presenting the card personally. This is an anti-business measure so it is no wonder that the Government is suppressing the business regulation review report on the legislation.
THE CONSCRIPTION OF BUSINESS AND THE COMMUNITY AS THE ENFORCERS
Employers, (this includes you employing a babysitter) face fines of $20,000 for simply failing to ask an employee for their ID card and/or reporting the number and wages to the tax commissioner.

Banks, real estate agents, stock brokers, stock and station agents, produce merchants, all other financial institutions, even people loaning money in the family, face similar fines for failing to record their client's card number and business transactions for transmission to the tax office-all these fines are multiplied by five if you are a company, this could be the local ``Golf Club Inc''. Yet by comparison, the fine for giving false information to get a card is only $5,000, and the penalties for improper disclosure are derisory.
THE COST IS HUGE

Even by the Government's estimates, (proved to be low in the past), the cost to achieve an up and running system is approximately $800 million. Two thousand public servants are required for general administration. No one has estimated the additional police, judges and gaol warders needed to enforce the penalties. Two billion dollars of tax payers' money is a more likely guess.

The basic rule in such matters is that if Government spends one dollar, the community cost is three dollars. The Government has received advice on this matter from its specially convened committee, the business review unit. The Government refuses to release this report. Clearly its findings regarding the community cost is embarrassing to Mr Hawke. The banking industry alone says the cost to validate bank accounts will exceed $60m, Westpac estimates of cost per account could mean a cost closer to $300m, and this cost will be passed on. Retailers will go through a period when it will be necessary to phone the bank each time a cheque is presented to them to ensure the account is operable and has been validated with an ID number.
Much business will be lost as people delay or discontinue transactions because its gets too complicated.
IT WILL NOT WORK

The Government's stated claim is that the card will wipe out tax evasion and welfare fraud. International experience is that the very reverse will apply. The more the card is accepted as a universal identifier, the easier it will be for criminals to use it as evidence of false identity. The private sector in particular will have no means of checking that a person is the rightful holder of a particular card. Photographs, even fingerprints can be of the forger, whilst other card details are of some other person. The Department of Social Security has already said it will not accept the card as sole evidence of identity and they will have computerised access to additional back-up evidence including a digitised photo recorded on computer. Dr Blewett says forged cards may be hard to detect. So what hope has a bank of identifying a false card used to open a bank account in your name by some criminal, who later closes the account and leaves you to explain the interest earned and the source of the original funds to the tax man. No wonder Costigan, the Australian Federal Police and Inspector Merv Beck call on us not to proceed with the card. Forging credit cards is a highly sophisticated, world wide industry and recent court cases in Western Australia show how students managed to forge cards suitable to withdraw money from other people's accounts through automatic bank tellers. Please remember, getting your number is as simple as asking for it, or if not, by requesting it of an employee of your employer, bank, real estate agent and so forth.

The Government further believes for instance, that genuine cheats will be so naive as to leave their false bank accounts in place once a card is necessary. Obviously, when confronted with legalising their accounts, they will withdraw the money and close the account. The card has no control over cash transactions unless of course the government requires the production of a card on every occasion of a cash purchase and if it is reasonable to accept the card for the reasons already stated, when is it reasonable to demand it be used for everything? Mr Hawke cannot commit future governments and his own promises have not been worth much in the past.

The Treasurer's own written explanation (notes on Clauses 32 to 51) on clause 49 says although employers must demand to see the card, failure to produce it should not `prohibit' one getting a job. This is an open invitation to those, particularly in seasonal employment, to work under assumed names whilst retaining the dole under their correct identity. The only penalty will be a high tax rate which will be a cheap price to pay for keeping full-time social security benefits.
It all adds to tough times for honest Australians and easy street for the cheats in our society. This is directly opposite to what the Government pretends.

It is obscene to use the word `Australia' to give credibility to this national compulsory identity system; it is ridiculous to claim the Government has a mandate for the Card when a majority of electors in the last election voted for Parties clearly opposed to the Card. I now challenge them to let the people of Australia decide the issue
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM (REFERENCE TO THE PEOPLE) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to ensure that the Australia Card Act 1987 does not come into operation unless the national identification system proposed to be established by the Act has been first approved by a majority of Australian electors, voting at a referendum.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Federal Government's proposed national identification system, to be implemented via the Australia Card Bill, is one of the most far-reaching and significant proposals ever to come before this Parliament.

At the time the Government first mooted the ID card proposal at the Tax Summit in 1985, the Australian Democrats warned that the suggestion involved very serious civil liberties aspects and that the efficacy of the proposal would need to be carefully examined.

So concerned were we, in fact, that later that year I negotiated with the Health Minister and the Opposition spokesperson to establish a joint Parliamentary Committee to enquire into the proposals and its alternatives.

In the event, a majority of the Committee, of which I was one and which included representatives of all political parties, recommended against the ID card and suggested the use of a high integrity tax-file number to address the undoubtedly serious problem of tax cheats and social security fraud.

Since then, the Government has arrogantly ignored not only the Committee's findings, but also the opinions of a wide range of experts who have expressed strong opposition to the card and the system. These opponents of the card include crime and tax evasion experts like Frank Costigan QC, computer experts, legal bodies including the Law Council of Australia, Councils for Civil Liberties throughout the country and both employer and union bodies.

Deaf to this comprehensive body of opinion, the Government proceeded to introduce its deceptively-named Australia Card Bill into the Parliament where it has been defeated twice and then called a double dissolution using the Bill as a trigger.

Since the election, community concern about the implications of the ID card has mounted as more and more people have become aware of the contents of the Bill. I do not intend to detail here the very real dangers and immense cost of this proposal because that will be done later this week in this Chamber. Suffice to say that the scheme is unworkable, expensive and dangerous and it distracts attention from the task of finding real solutions to tax and social security fraud.

We have now reached the point where, after the Government has presented the Bill again and it is defeated in the Senate, a joint Sitting can be called. Since the Government's new majority exceeds the numbers against it in the Senate, it will be able to push the Bill through unamended. Certainly the opponents of the Bill in this Chamber will combine to ensure that the Bill is properly examined by a Committee, but the Government's actions so far suggest that they would ignore any argument or finding, no matter how compelling.

There is one opinion, however, that the Government cannot ignore-the voice of the Australian people. The Government has claimed, of course, that it has a mandate to proceed with the ID card by virtue of the Australia Card Bill being the trigger for the double dissolution. Any objective examination of the issues which featured in the election campaign would expose this claim as nonsense. To suggest that the election result can be interpreted as support for the identification system and card is absurd.

However, if the Government is so confident that it has the support of the Australian people on the ID card issue, it will have no difficulty in supporting this Bill. On a matter as important as a national identification system, far more important than many other matters that have gone to referenda, a referendum is the only answer. The Australian people are entitled to express their view about this proposal and its implications for the future. Consistent with their general support for citizens' initiative referenda, the Australian Democrats want this matter to be decided by those who will be most affected by its implementation-Australian citizens. It is difficult to see how any party could argue with that approach and I am confident this Chamber will support the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, in pursuance of section 13 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth, the Senators chosen for each State be divided into two classes as follows:
(1) The name of the Senator first elected shall be placed first on the Senators' Roll for each State and the name of the Senator next elected shall be placed next, and so on in rotation.

(2) The Senators whose names are placed first, second, third, fourth, fifth and sixth on the Roll shall be Senators of the second class, that is, the long-term Senators, and the Senators whose names are placed seventh, eighth, ninth, tenth, eleventh and twelfth on the Roll shall be Senators of the first class, that is, the short-term Senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition sees no reason either in logic or in ethics to accept the Government's motion. The only reason that the Government has moved this motion is one of cynical political gain. That is the reason why yesterday, on behalf of the Opposition, I gave notice of a motion which runs in effect totally counter to the Government's motion, to enable the system of election, in order, of senators that was agreed to by the Senate in 1983 to come into effect at the first opportunity that it could be put to the test, that is, today. As my motion will not be debated because of Senate procedures, I move the following amendment to the Government's motion to bring to the Senate's attention the motion of which I gave notice yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out paragraph (2), insert the following paragraph:

``(2) The six Senators for each State whose order of election was determined in a re-count of ballot papers pursuant to section 282 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and certified by the Australian Electoral Officer for that State shall be Senators of the second class, that is, the long-term Senators, and the remaining six Senators for that State shall be Senators of the first class, that is, the short-term Senators.''.

Section 13 of the Constitution provides that we senators shall decide who will serve in the long term and who will serve in the short term Senate positions in the event of a double dissolution. Until now the practice for deciding who will be long or short terms senators has been the one that the Government now proposes; that is, that the method of counting the votes at a Federal election when there is a double dissolution should determine the order of classification into long and short term senators. That system came into operation many years ago and it had its first use in the days of block voting for the Senate. When the Senate moved to proportional representation in 1949, that had the effect of changing the importance of the votes cast for the first elected for each party. The absurd situation which the old practice throws up is one to which the Senate's mind was addressed in 1983 after very lengthy, serious and important deliberation by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. One of the things that that Committee threw up was the absurdity of the situation where simply the election of senators, after a double dissolution, on the basis of the order determined on the smaller quota for senators which double dissolutions provide, can lead to the situation where, for example, a minority party senator with less than 8 per cent of the vote-in fact with 7.8 per cent of the vote-could get a long term, a six year term, whereas a major party that may have polled 45 per cent of the vote would still end up with only two long term senators. That is a situation that all parties in this chamber-certainly all major parties and I think the minor parties as well-agree was absurd.

When the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform looked at the matter it agreed that the old practice resulted in confusion, that it was the subject of political manoeuvrings and that it did in fact encourage the promotion of double dissolutions. The Joint Select Committee therefore recommended that the past practice be changed by the insertion in the Commonwealth Electoral Act of a new clause which would enable senators to be ordered in terms or short and long term on the basis of the election having been a half Senate election rather than a double dissolution election. The implication, of course, is the very significant effect that that has on the quota required for any senator to be elected.

The Select Committee made two recommendations. It recommended first of all that following a double dissolution election the Australian Electoral Commission conduct, as I said, a second count of Senate votes using the half Senate quota in order to establish the order of election to the Senate and therefore, very importantly, the terms of election. The Committee also recommended that the practice of ranking senators in accordance with their relative success at an election be submitted to electors at a referendum for incorporation in the Constitution by way of amendment so that the issue is placed beyond doubt and removed from the political arena. It is very important to note that those two recommendations were not dependent upon one another. They are two separate recommendations. The first of those recommendations was enshrined in the Commonwealth Electoral Act in November-December 1983. The second recommendation, concerning an amendment to the Constitution, has not yet been adopted. However, that in no way alters or lessens the significance of the recommendation which flowed through and is now law in the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

This is the first occasion on which the amendment made in 1983 to the Commonwealth Electoral Act has been put to the test. This is the first time since 1983 that there has been a double dissolution election. I believe that what we are looking at today is a very important issue because we as a Senate are being asked to put to the test, to adopt or not to adopt in usage, the unanimous recommendation of a joint select committee of this Parliament which was agreed to by this Senate less than four years ago without any amendment or dissension. It was a very sensible and desirable amendment. As I said, all parties agreed to the amendment. So, the first question that the Government needs to answer in relation to this motion is why is it going back on the decision that this Senate made in 1983. I repeat, no party formally disagreed with the amendment in 1983. There was no vote on it. As I understand it, there was no reservation by any member of the Joint Select Committee to the proposal concerning the new method of determining ordering in Senate elections.

Senator Macklin, the Democrat senator on that Committee, made no dissenting report and, indeed, when the matter came up for debate in the Committee of the Whole, Senator Macklin went to great pains to make the clause, which is now section 282 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, more clear, precise and accurate than the Government had proposed in its amendment to the Bill. Indeed, Senator Macklin's amendment was accepted by the Committee of the Whole.
The Government's motion is a cynical and unprincipled one. The Senate agreed to use this new system--

TALK.START.PARA: —It did not. It never agreed.

—I will come to Senator Ray's words in a moment. It is obvious that the effect of the Government's motion is to give two additional long term Senate positions to the Democrats and two less long term positions to the National Party of Australia. Therefore, what this does is enshrine and give great advantage to a minority party in the form of the Democrats. There is no doubt at all that a deal has been done here between the Government--
—A pack of lies.

—The honourable senator will get his chance to answer in a moment. It is quite obvious that a deal has been done between the Government and the Democrats, a party which once originally prided itself on keeping the bastards honest. I am afraid that this time the Government has colluded with that Party. That is an absolutely--
—Not true.
—That is an absolutely ludicrous situation.
—That is not true and you know it.
—If it is not true we will look forward to hearing Senator Ray's explanation, which has not been given up to date, as to why the Government has moved this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unusual for me ever to quote Senator Vigor, who was in this chamber until recently and who I noticed came back yesterday. It was a great pleasure to see him in the gallery yesterday. Just prior to his leaving the Senate, Senator Vigor made a very important contribution by telling the people of Australia a little bit about the change that has taken place over recent years in the situation of the Australian Democrats. On 4 June, in what was almost his final speech in this place, Senator Vigor drew attention to the early days of the Australian Democrats and their present position. He said:
When the Australian Democrats were founded the Party was based on democratic principles of openness and fair dealing, with honesty, tolerance and compassion as guiding principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a long time ago.

—It certainly was. I think he was wrong there, anyway. But even accepting that there is a little bit of correctness in what he said, he certainly put us straight as to the present situation. He then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The honesty, tolerance and compassion have been replaced with introverted suspicions of anybody who falls mildly outside the expected dedication to a number of fairly narrow views.

This was a very honest, open statement by Senator Vigor who was absolutely massacred by his Party in its refusal to allow him to stand in a winning position for a Senate seat. I have to say that on occasions Senator Vigor spoke with a lot of common sense and honesty, and that was certainly one of those occasions. Senator Ray played a very important and very welcome role-one that was highly applauded by all parties in the Senate-in the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Mr President, the Budget for 1987-88 is in balance.
The deficit has been cut to just on zero, a mere $27 million.
This Government, having inherited a prospective budget deficit of almost $10,000 million, the largest in the Nation's history, has in the space of just 5 budgets wiped that dismal legacy out.
What is more, this monumental achievement has been accomplished while keeping to our election commitments not to increase taxes and not to make major additional spending cuts.
Relative to the size of the economy, tax revenue is down on last year.
On the same basis, government spending is down two percentage points compared with the level confronting us in 1983.
This Budget incorporates nonetheless significant new initiatives.
We have provided $250 million to meet our election commitment to a Family Allowance Supplement for low income families.
We have financed the massive $4,500 million cost of the personal income tax cuts introduced in December last year and July this year.
We have introduced a new company tax system which eliminates the double taxation of dividends.
These achievements have been made possible while simultaneously balancing the Budget by the most wide ranging and detailed review of government spending ever carried out.
This Budget incorporates a 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending, the biggest cut in the 35 years for which comparable records are available.
This Budget also lays the foundations for sound budgets over the life of this Parliament.
The decisions which have cut outlays by $3,500 million this year will produce the same reductions next year.
In other words, the savings are on-going.
THE GOVERNMENT'S ECONOMIC STRATEGY

Mr President, this fundamental shift down in the Commonwealth budget is making a crucial contribution to the process of adjustment that Australia has been undergoing since the collapse in our export prices in 1985-86.
Unlike almost any other economy in similar circumstances, the Australian economy has not been driven into recession.
The Government's policy response has been innovative, strong, and most of all, right.
Notwithstanding the enormity of the trade difficulties we have faced, our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.
Australians have responded earnestly by lifting the national export effort and successfully seeking out new markets.
No less than half of Australia's export growth last year came from the sale of manufactured goods-a remarkable achievement given the parlous state of manufacturing only 4 years ago.
We are also developing services such as tourism into major earners of foreign exchange.
At the same time we have cut imports by making locally more of the goods we used to buy from overseas.
Taken together, increased exports and reduced imports accounted for all of Australia's economic growth last year.
One hundred and forty thousand new jobs were created.
Our trading bill was cut by $1,000 million from 6 per cent of Gross Domestic Product to 5 per cent.
In this coming year we forecast that it will decline further to 4 per cent.
These achievements are extremely gratifying.
They have exceeded the expectations of almost everybody.
Mr President, as successful as we have been, the magnitude of our trading problem is such that we still have a long way to go.
The big trade deficits since the early 1980s have built up a substantial foreign debt burden.
Our external deficit, although falling, remains too high.
To reduce permanently our debt burden we must go further in reducing our dependence on overseas savings by lifting the level of Australian savings.
This is why we have acted to cut the demands of all levels of government on savings, releasing them for private investment to enhance our trade performance.
But that is only part of the story.
If Australia is to sell more abroad-and if our manufacturers are to win a greater share of the domestic market-we must ensure that the goods we produce are priced competitively.
In particular, we must make sure that labour costs in Australia are competitive with those of our trading partners.
The Australian community has shown enormous maturity and commonsense in responding to the trade crisis by exercising wage restraint.
This has helped sustain the new-found competitiveness of Australian industry.
Most importantly it has ensured that the difficult international trading conditions have not led to a surge in unemployment.

This is being reinforced by the two tier wage system which for the first time in our history is requiring efficiency and productivity improvements at an industry and enterprise level as offsets for wage increases.
In the public sector the Commonwealth is insisting that any second tier wage increase granted to its own employees be offset by genuine productivity and efficiency gains.
EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING
Mr President, if Australia is to compete successfully in the international market place we must also raise our educational standards.
We are now redirecting our spending so that it better conforms with Australia's economic priorities.

In May I announced a major restructuring of unemployment benefits and study allowances which greatly increases the incentives for our young people to stay in the education and training system rather than moving onto welfare.
The centrepiece of those reforms was the abolition of unemployment benefits for 16 and 17 year olds and the substitution of a modest job search allowance.

This restructuring of study allowances has been carried further in the Budget by changes to the student assistance schemes for Aboriginal children, isolated children and the children of veterans, bringing them more into line with mainstream income support programs.
The Government also recognises that if we are to encourage young people to stay in the education system, we must provide more student places.
Consequently we have approved an extra 5,800 higher education places for young school leavers in 1988.
Our reforms in education and training have also been geared to getting better value for money.

From 1988 funds for new TAFE capital works will be allocated on the basis of competitive bidding by States and individual colleges, with priority being given to projects in economically important areas, such as computing studies and hospitality, and areas which involve joint funding with industry.
Funding for the Australian Traineeship System-which provides young people entering the workforce with a mixture of on-the-job and formal training-is to increase from $14 million to $45 million.
This will provide places for 13,000 new trainees.
At a cost of $31 million, a new program to provide short-term vocational training opportunities for unemployed young people will be introduced.
My colleague, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, will issue tonight a comprehensive paper explaining the Government's skills formation strategy.
Among other measures, $15 million will be provided in 1987-88 and $28 million in a full year to implement a National Policy on Languages.
Funding for the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy will be increased by $26 million in 1987-88 and by $49 million in 1988-89.
FAMILY ASSISTANCE PACKAGE
Mr President, the Hawke Government has always believed that only those in genuine need should be entitled to social security payments.
We have systematically implemented measures to exclude welfare cheats from the system.
In the May Statement I described a range of further initiatives to crack down on fraud and abuse.
Already these are proving very successful.
As a result of these measures we will save more than $100 million in unemployment benefit payments in 1987-88.
We have consistently held that people who can readily support themselves should do so, rather than putting their hand out to the taxpayer.
But we have not shirked the Australian Labor Party's historical commitment to assist the most needy in our community.
This Budget further strengthens that commitment by implementing a landmark social reform in the shape of the Family Assistance Package.
From Christmas this year this package will provide help to more than half a million families in need.
More than one million children will benefit.
Subject to an income test, the new scheme will provide a Family Allowance Supplement of $22 per week per child.
Recognising the higher costs associated with teenage children, the payment for each child aged 13, 14, or 15 will be $28 per week.
In addition, we will provide low income families renting privately with an extra allowance of up to $15 a week.
This means, for example, that families with income up to $324 per week who rent privately and have three children, two aged under 13 and one 14, will receive a supplement of $87 per week free of tax.
That is an increase of up to $69 per week on what they would have received under the old Family Income Supplement.
The most any of these families would have received under the discredited election tax policy of the Liberal and National Parties would have been $20.46.
This new Family Allowance Supplement is additional to the existing Family Allowance and will be paid directly to the primary carer of the children, generally the mother.
It is structured so that it will increase the incentive for unemployed people to find work and will provide a positive inducement to avoid welfare dependency.
In terms of assisting low income families in genuine need, this new Family Allowance Supplement ranks with any initiative introduced by any Australian government in any period.
As I said earlier, this is a landmark change in social policy and a source of much pride to the Government.
HEALTH
As promised in the election campaign, the Government will provide $25 million to the States this year and next to reduce waiting lists in public hospitals.
Expenditure of $20 million will be provided for prevention and education measures to combat the spread of AIDS.
Following a review of requirements, repatriation hospital staff numbers are to be increased by 337.
STAFF AND ADMINISTRATION
The Prime Minister recently announced a major restructuring of Commonwealth departments.
These changes are estimated to produce savings of $107 million in a full year and to cut 3,100 off staffing levels by 1988-89
ASSET SALES
In May the Government announced a program of asset sales estimated to yield about $1,000 million in 1987-88.

In order to maintain maximum flexibility in aviation policy, and in the light of our election commitment to deregulate the industry, the Government has decided not to proceed with the sale of its international airport terminals.
Notwithstanding this change, however, we still expect the other elements of the program of asset sales announced in May to raise at least $1,000 million in 1987-88.
In the 1988-89 financial year we will be selling the loans portfolio of the Defence Service Homes Corporation and other defence assets, producing savings of around another $1,000 million.
As well as generating important efficiency gains, this will add a recurrent quality to the budgetary numbers as far as the disposal program is concerned.
REVENUE
Turning to the revenue side, I repeat that we have adhered to our election commitment not to increase taxes or introduce new taxes.

We have been able to cut spending and taxes at the same time partly because we are now reaping the benefits of earlier actions to restore integrity to the tax system and to upgrade its administration.

The capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and related measures like many things that are new, were controversial at inception, but are now fulfilling their proper structural function by massively broadening the tax base.
It is largely because of these measures that despite legislated lower tax rates and subdued economic growth, 1986-87 tax collections came in $1 billion above budget-time estimates.
Not only are they yielding the revenue but they have made the system much fairer than it has ever been.

The Government is firmly committed to continuing its efforts to make the tax and welfare systems decent and secure, and consequently we will proceed with vigour to implement the Australia Card national identification system.
This system will return up to $1,000 million a year in revenue that is presently being evaded or defrauded.

SPEECH.PARA: As most Australians are aware, some people in this country have accumulated substantial wealth because of booming stock-market and property values.

Under the old tax system much of those profits would have gone tax-free-and I interpolate that under the tax system proposed by the Opposition two months ago, they would also have gone tax-free. That is no longer the case.

We have made the system fairer and those who have previously benefited from tax-free capital profits are now making a substantial contribution towards the costs of government services like schools, roads, social security, and so on.
The impact of this new, fair tax has been a fundamental factor in the Government's review of tax deductions for investors in rental property.

Since we have restored the integrity of the tax system by subjecting capital gains to tax, we are now in a position to permit the restoration of deductions against taxable income without exposing the revenue to the threat which existed before July 1985.
The full interest costs of owning and maintaining rental property will now be deductible against income from any source.
In the recent past the Government has canvassed in detail the principle of allowing tax deductions for interest costs in the case of both rural investments and equity investments.
In both cases we decided in favour of allowing offsetting deductions.
Tonight's decision restores the symmetry between investment in property and other assets such as shares or farms.
It will enhance the attractiveness of in- vestment in both commercial and residential rental property and have a beneficial effect on the supply of residential accommodation in particular.
In the light of this decision the 4 per cent depreciation allowance for both residential and non-residential construction is to be reduced to 2 1/2 per cent for new properties.
This will moderate the cost of these concessions, which has been growing at an annual rate of $55 million, while still representing a substantial concession to construction activity.
NEW POLICY DIRECTIONS

Following introduction of the Government's revolutionary full imputation system for company tax-to remove the double tax on dividends-the Government has now instituted a complementary review within the Treasury of the remaining structure of the business taxation system.
The overriding objective of this review is to identify options for financing reductions in the company tax rate through sensible broadening of the company income tax base.
This is in line with similar recent reforms in a number of major Western economies, including the United States and Britain.
The outcome of that review will be announced either in or before the next Budget.
In the coming term the Government will be concentrating its energies on the quest for efficiency throughout the economy.
We have already foreshadowed the removal of outdated regulatory arrangements in the crude oil industry and the aviation sector.
More reforms of this nature will follow as we review and remove impediments to doing things better in different sectors of the economy.
FUTURE PROSPECTS
Australia's economic performance will continue to be constrained until we overcome the fundamental problem of our trade imbalance.
Even so, in the coming year Australia's economic growth rate is estimated to increase modestly from 2 per cent last financial year to 2 3/4 per cent.
This should generate over 100,000 new jobs-meaning that by the end of our Bicentennial year one million new jobs will have been created since the Hawke Government first won office.
Continued buoyancy of employment, and the tax cuts, will lift household purchasing power from last year's low.
But the cuts we have made to government spending will restrain total domestic demand and avoid any spillover into unsustainable import pressures.
Now that we have eliminated the budget deficit we will be repaying $1,000 million of Commonwealth overseas debt this year and the same amount of domestic bonds.
No other Commonwealth government in more than 50 years has made repayments of both external and domestic debt in the same year.
This year we have seen significant falls in interest rates, both for businesses and for home buyers.
The withdrawal of the Commonwealth Government as a net borrower this year will further reduce pressures on financial markets and help to sustain those lower interest rates.
While fiscal policy is now carrying more of the burden of policy, monetary policy will continue to play its proper role in containing domestic demand and cost and price pressures.

Lower interest rates and an improving economic climate should contribute to a lift in business investment of at least 4 per cent in real terms and much more than that in the areas taking advantage of new export and import competing opportunities.
We therefore expect that Australia will make further substantial progress in reducing the current account deficit in 1987-88.
It should fall to around $11 1/2 billion, 4 percent of Gross Domestic Product.

With the worst of the inflationary impact of the depreciation of the dollar behind us, and wage restraint under the Accord, inflation is expected to fall from over 9 per cent last year to around 6 per cent by the middle of 1988.
CONCLUSION
Finally, Mr President, I have described tonight how Australia is successfully responding to the most adverse external economic difficulty we have faced since the Great Depression nearly 60 years ago.
We could have reacted to this trade deterioration by pushing all the economic policy levers into reverse.
That has been tried in the past, both here and in other countries.

And where it has been tried it has not produced the quick results hoped for and it has resulted in sharply higher long-term levels of unemployment, declining living standards and destructive social conflicts.
We have rejected that path and the events of the last 18 months have shown that we were right.
We have turned the corner and the big gaps in the trade accounts have begun to close.

Essential to our success to date has been cutting the size of government and pulling down the Budget deficit from the near $10,000 million that we inherited from Mr Fraser and Mr Howard to just on zero.
